ChatGPT

To implement the constructWorkSpace method where you can draw WordBlock items and allow for drag-and-drop functionality, you will likely want to use a JPanel with custom painting and mouse handling. Here's how you can start implementing this:

  1. Create a custom panel class for rendering WordBlock items.
  2. Implement painting logic to draw squares or rectangles representing each WordBlock.
  3. Add mouse listeners to handle drag-and-drop functionality.

Here's an example of how you might implement this:

java
import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.event.MouseAdapter;
import java.awt.event.MouseEvent;
import java.awt.event.MouseMotionAdapter;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

// Custom panel to represent the workspace
class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel {
    private Map<WordBlock, Rectangle> wordBlockRectangles = new HashMap<>();
    private WordBlock draggedWordBlock;
    private Point lastDragPoint;

    public WorkSpacePanel() {
        setBackground(Color.WHITE); // Set a background color different from black to see the words
        setupMouseHandling();
    }

    private void setupMouseHandling() {
        MouseAdapter mouseAdapter = new MouseAdapter() {
            @Override
            public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
                for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Rectangle> entry : wordBlockRectangles.entrySet()) {
                    if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
                        draggedWordBlock = entry.getKey();
                        lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();
                        break;
                    }
                }
            }

            @Override
            public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e) {
                draggedWordBlock = null;
                lastDragPoint = null;
            }
        };

        MouseMotionAdapter motionAdapter = new MouseMotionAdapter() {
            @Override
            public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) {
                if (draggedWordBlock != null && lastDragPoint != null) {
                    int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x;
                    int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y;
                    Rectangle rect = wordBlockRectangles.get(draggedWordBlock);
                    rect.translate(dx, dy);
                    lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();
                    repaint(); // Repaint the panel to reflect the change
                }
            }
        };

        addMouseListener(mouseAdapter);
        addMouseMotionListener(motionAdapter);
    }

    public void addWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) {
        // Assuming WordBlock has a method to get its position
        wordBlockRectangles.put(wordBlock, new Rectangle(wordBlock.getPosition(), new Dimension(50, 50)));
    }

    @Override
    protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
        super.paintComponent(g);
        for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Rectangle> entry : wordBlockRectangles.entrySet()) {
            WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey();
            Rectangle rect = entry.getValue();
            g.setColor(getColorForWordBlock(wordBlock));
            g.fillRect(rect.x, rect.y, rect.width, rect.height);
        }
    }

    private Color getColorForWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) {
        // This method would return a color based on the WordBlock properties, for example:
        return switch (wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech()) {
            case NOUN -> Color.BLUE;
            case VERB -> Color.RED;
            // Add cases for other parts of speech
            default -> Color.GRAY;
        };
    }
}

In your App class, you can integrate this WorkSpacePanel:

java
private void constructWorkSpace() {
    WorkSpacePanel workSpacePanel = new WorkSpacePanel();
    // Here, you should add WordBlock items to your workSpacePanel
    // For example, if you have a method to get WordBlocks:
    // for (WordBlock wordBlock : model.getWorkSpaceWordBlocks()) {
    //     workSpacePanel.addWordBlock(wordBlock);
    // }

    this.workSpacePanel = workSpacePanel; // Assuming this is the panel you'll add to your split pane
}

In the example above, WorkSpacePanel is a custom JPanel that draws rectangles for each WordBlock and handles drag-and-drop. Adjust the logic inside getColorForWordBlock to fit how you want to visualize different types of WordBlock instances.

This setup will allow you to visually represent WordBlock items in the workspace and move them around with the mouse. The position handling here is very basic and intended to demonstrate the concept; you may need to refine it according to your application's needs, especially for updating the model with new positions after drag-and-drop operations.

You
Method paintComponent does not override method from its superclass
2 / 2
ChatGPT

The paintComponent method is intended to override a method from the JComponent class, which JPanel extends. If you're getting an error saying that paintComponent does not override a method from its superclass, it could be due to a mismatch in the method signature.

Ensure that the method signature for paintComponent exactly matches what is expected. It should take a single parameter of type Graphics and should be protected. Also, it's important to call super.paintComponent(g) within the method to ensure that the panel is properly rendered before you add custom painting logic.

Here is the correct way to override the paintComponent method in the WorkSpacePanel class:

java
@Override
protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
    super.paintComponent(g); // Always call super.paintComponent to handle standard painting logic
    // Your custom painting code here
}

Make sure you have the correct import for Graphics:

java
import java.awt.Graphics;

Here's how you should integrate it within the context of the custom panel:

java
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import java.awt.Color;
import java.awt.Dimension;
import java.awt.Graphics;
import java.awt.Point;
import java.awt.Rectangle;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel {
    private Map<WordBlock, Rectangle> wordBlockRectangles = new HashMap<>();

    // Your existing constructor and methods...

    @Override
    protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
        super.paintComponent(g);
        for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Rectangle> entry : wordBlockRectangles.entrySet()) {
            WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey();
            Rectangle rect = entry.getValue();
            g.setColor(getColorForWordBlock(wordBlock));
            g.fillRect(rect.x, rect.y, rect.width, rect.height);
        }
    }

    private Color getColorForWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) {
        // Return a color based on the WordBlock properties
        // Dummy implementation:
        return Color.BLUE; // Replace with actual logic
    }
}

This setup defines a custom paintComponent method for WorkSpacePanel that will properly render the contents of the panel according to your custom painting logic.

You

import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock; import LinguaLink.logger.Logger; import LinguaLink.components.word.PartOfSpeech; import LinguaLink.components.word.Word; import LinguaLink.uiComponents.ComplexCellRenderer; if (!wordText.isEmpty()) { Word newWord = new Word(wordText, selectedPos); controller.addWordBankElement(newWord); wordInput.setText(""); // Clear input field } else { Logger.error("Empty word string could not be added to WordBank"); } }); inputPanel.add(addButton); // Create the word list model wordListRender = new DefaultListModel<>(); // Create the JList and set it to use the word list model JList<Word> wordList = new JList<>(wordListRender); wordList.setCellRenderer(new ComplexCellRenderer()); wordList.setSelectionMode(ListSelectionModel.SINGLE_SELECTION); wordList.addMouseListener(new MouseAdapter() { @Override public void mouseClicked(MouseEvent e) { if (e.getClickCount() == 2) { int index = wordList.locationToIndex(e.getPoint()); if (index >= 0) { Word selectedWord = wordList.getModel().getElementAt(index); controller.moveWordToWorkSpace(selectedWord); } } } }); // Add JList to a scroll pane (in case of many entries) JScrollPane listScroller = new JScrollPane(wordList); listScroller.setBorder(null); // Create a split pane to hold both the input panel and the list scroller JSplitPane splitPane = new JSplitPane( JSplitPane.VERTICAL_SPLIT, inputPanel, listScroller); splitPane.setResizeWeight(0); // The inputPanel area will not expand with the window size splitPane.setDividerLocation(75); // You can adjust this value as needed splitPane.setOneTouchExpandable(false); // Disable the one-touch expandable buttons splitPane.setEnabled(false); // Disable the divider so it can't be moved splitPane.setDividerSize(0); // Add the split pane to the wordBankPanel wordBankPanel.add(splitPane, BorderLayout.CENTER); return wordBankPanel; } private JPanel constructWorkSpace() { WorkSpacePanel workSpacePanel = new WorkSpacePanel(); for (WordBlock wordBlock : model.getWorkSpaceWordBlocks()) { workSpacePanel.addWordBlock(wordBlock); } return workSpacePanel; } private void setupMainAndSideLayout() { JPanel wordBank = constructWordBank(); JPanel workSpacePanel = constructWorkSpace(); JSplitPane splitPane = new JSplitPane(JSplitPane.HORIZONTAL_SPLIT, workSpacePanel, wordBank); splitPane.setSize(1920, 1080); splitPane.setDividerLocation(0.8); splitPane.setOneTouchExpandable(false); // Disable the one-touch expandable buttons splitPane.setEnabled(false); // Disable the divider so it can't be moved splitPane.setDividerSize(0); getContentPane().add(splitPane, BorderLayout.CENTER); } @Override public void update() { // Refresh UI components based on the updated model refreshWordBank(); refreshWorkSpace(); } private void refreshWordBank() { List<Word> currentWords = model.getWordBankWords(); wordListRender.clear(); for (Word word : currentWords) { wordListRender.addElement(word); } Logger.info("WordBank updated."); } private void refreshWorkSpace() { } public static void main(String[] args) { SwingUtilities.invokeLater(() -> new App().setVisible(true)); } }
ChatGPT

To implement refreshWorkSpace that redraws all WordBlock items in the workspace whenever update is called, you need to ensure that workSpacePanel can be accessed and manipulated correctly within your App class. Since workSpacePanel is a custom panel for rendering WordBlock items, it should support adding, removing, and redrawing these items.

Here's how you can implement refreshWorkSpace:

  1. Ensure workSpacePanel is a field in your App class so that it can be accessed from any method.
  2. In refreshWorkSpace, clear the current WordBlock items from the workSpacePanel and add them back from the model to reflect any changes.

Here's the updated App class with refreshWorkSpace implemented:

java
import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock;
import LinguaLink.uiComponents.workSpacePanel.WorkSpacePanel;

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;

public class App extends JFrame implements ModelObserver {
    private Model model;
    private Controller controller;
    private JPanel wordBankPanel;
    private WorkSpacePanel workSpacePanel; // Changed to WorkSpacePanel for custom rendering
    private DefaultListModel<Word> wordListRender;

    public App() {
        super("Interactive Language Learning Tool");
        model = Model.getInstance();
        model.addObserver(this);
        controller = Controller.getInstance();
        initUI();
    }

    private void initUI() {
        setupMenuBar();
        setupMainAndSideLayout();
        setSize(1920, 1080);
        setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
    }

    // Existing methods...

    private JPanel constructWorkSpace() {
        workSpacePanel = new WorkSpacePanel(); // Assign to the field

        return workSpacePanel;
    }

    private void setupMainAndSideLayout() {
        JPanel wordBank = constructWordBank();
        constructWorkSpace(); // Construct workSpacePanel and assign it to the field
        JSplitPane splitPane = new JSplitPane(JSplitPane.HORIZONTAL_SPLIT, workSpacePanel, wordBank);
        // Additional setup...
    }

    @Override
    public void update() {
        refreshWordBank();
        refreshWorkSpace();
    }

    private void refreshWorkSpace() {
        // Assuming WorkSpacePanel has methods to clear and add WordBlocks
        workSpacePanel.clearWordBlocks(); // Clear existing WordBlocks

        for (WordBlock wordBlock : model.getWorkSpaceWordBlocks()) {
            workSpacePanel.addWordBlock(wordBlock); // Add WordBlocks from the model
        }

        workSpacePanel.repaint(); // Repaint to show the updated WordBlocks
    }

    // The main method...
}

In this setup:

  • workSpacePanel is an instance of WorkSpacePanel, which is assumed to be a custom JPanel that can handle WordBlock rendering.
  • constructWorkSpace initializes workSpacePanel and assigns it to the class field.
  • refreshWorkSpace clears the current WordBlock items from the workSpacePanel and then repopulates it using WordBlock items from the model, followed by a repaint call to update the display.

You need to implement the clearWordBlocks, addWordBlock, and getWorkSpaceWordBlocks methods in the respective classes (WorkSpacePanel and Model) to support these operations. clearWordBlocks should remove all WordBlock items from the WorkSpacePanel, addWordBlock should add a new WordBlock to the panel, and getWorkSpaceWordBlocks should return the list of WordBlock items in the model that need to be displayed in the workspace.

You
You never implemented clearWordBlocks() in the WorkSpacePanel class. How would I implement this to clear all present WordBlocks?:
ChatGPT

To implement clearWordBlocks() in the WorkSpacePanel class, you need to clear the data structure holding the WordBlock items and then repaint the panel to update the display. Assuming wordBlockRectangles is the map holding the WordBlock objects and their corresponding screen rectangles, here’s how you can implement it:

  1. Clear the Map: Remove all entries from wordBlockRectangles.
  2. Repaint the Panel: Call repaint() to refresh the display after the WordBlock items are removed.

Here is the updated WorkSpacePanel class with the clearWordBlocks method:

java
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import java.awt.Color;
import java.awt.Dimension;
import java.awt.Graphics;
import java.awt.Point;
import java.awt.Rectangle;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel {
    private Map<WordBlock, Rectangle> wordBlockRectangles = new HashMap<>();

    // Existing constructor and methods...

    public void clearWordBlocks() {
        wordBlockRectangles.clear(); // Remove all WordBlock entries
        repaint(); // Repaint the panel to update the display
    }

    @Override
    protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
        super.paintComponent(g);
        for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Rectangle> entry : wordBlockRectangles.entrySet()) {
            WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey();
            Rectangle rect = entry.getValue();
            g.setColor(getColorForWordBlock(wordBlock));
            g.fillRect(rect.x, rect.y, rect.width, rect.height);
        }
    }

    private Color getColorForWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) {
        // Dummy implementation, replace with actual logic
        return Color.BLUE;
    }
}

In this implementation:

  • clearWordBlocks() method clears the wordBlockRectangles map, which is used to track the WordBlock objects and their drawing information.
  • After clearing the map, repaint() is called to trigger the paintComponent method, which will redraw the panel without the removed WordBlock items.

This approach ensures that when clearWordBlocks() is called, the WorkSpacePanel will remove all representations of WordBlock items from its display, effectively clearing the workspace visually.

You
In addWordBlock(), I would like it to create the following instead of a just a plain rectangle: - rounded rectangle. - logs when it's been double clicked function handler - contains text for wordBlock.getWord().getWord() and wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech() package LinguaLink.guiComponents.workSpacePanel; import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock; import LinguaLink.Controller; import javax.swing.*; import java.awt.*; import java.awt.event.MouseAdapter; import java.awt.event.MouseEvent; import java.awt.event.MouseMotionAdapter; import java.util.HashMap; import java.util.Map; public class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel { private Map<WordBlock, Rectangle> wordBlockRectangles = new HashMap<>(); private WordBlock draggedWordBlock; private Point lastDragPoint; private Controller controller; public WorkSpacePanel() { controller = Controller.getInstance(); setBackground(Color.WHITE); // Set a background color different from black to see the words setupMouseHandling(); } private void setupMouseHandling() { MouseAdapter mouseAdapter = new MouseAdapter() { @Override public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) { for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Rectangle> entry : wordBlockRectangles.entrySet()) { if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) { draggedWordBlock = entry.getKey(); lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); break; } } } @Override public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e) { draggedWordBlock = null; lastDragPoint = null; } }; MouseMotionAdapter motionAdapter = new MouseMotionAdapter() { @Override public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) { if (draggedWordBlock != null && lastDragPoint != null) { int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x; int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y; Rectangle rect = wordBlockRectangles.get(draggedWordBlock); rect.translate(dx, dy); lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); controller.setWordBlockPosition(draggedWordBlock, dx, dy); repaint(); } } }; addMouseListener(mouseAdapter); addMouseMotionListener(motionAdapter); } public void addWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) { Rectangle newRectangle = new Rectangle(wordBlock.getPosition(), new Dimension(100, 50)); wordBlockRectangles.put(wordBlock, newRectangle); } public void clearWordBlocks() { wordBlockRectangles.clear(); } @Override protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) { super.paintComponent(g); for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Rectangle> entry : wordBlockRectangles.entrySet()) { WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey(); Rectangle rect = entry.getValue(); g.setColor(getColorForWordBlock(wordBlock)); g.fillRect(rect.x, rect.y, rect.width, rect.height); } } private Color getColorForWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) { // This method would return a color based on the WordBlock properties, for example: return switch (wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech()) { case NOUN -> Color.BLUE; case VERB -> Color.RED; // Add cases for other parts of speech default -> Color.GRAY; }; } }
2 / 2
ChatGPT

To extend the WorkSpacePanel with the functionalities you described, here's how you can modify it:

  1. Use RoundRectangle2D to draw rounded rectangles instead of plain ones.
  2. Add double-click handling in the mouse listener to log or handle double-click events.
  3. Draw text inside each rectangle for the WordBlock's word and part of speech.

Here is how you can implement these requirements:

java
package LinguaLink.guiComponents.workSpacePanel;

import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock;
import LinguaLink.logger.Logger;

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.event.MouseAdapter;
import java.awt.event.MouseEvent;
import java.awt.geom.RoundRectangle2D;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

public class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel {
    private Map<WordBlock, Shape> wordBlockShapes = new HashMap<>();
    private WordBlock draggedWordBlock;
    private Point lastDragPoint;

    public WorkSpacePanel() {
        setBackground(Color.WHITE);
        setupMouseHandling();
    }

    private void setupMouseHandling() {
        MouseAdapter mouseAdapter = new MouseAdapter() {
            @Override
            public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
                for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
                    if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
                        draggedWordBlock = entry.getKey();
                        lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();
                        break;
                    }
                }
            }

            @Override
            public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e) {
                draggedWordBlock = null;
                lastDragPoint = null;
            }

            @Override
            public void mouseClicked(MouseEvent e) {
                if (e.getClickCount() == 2) {
                    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
                        if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
                            WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey();
                            Logger.info("Double-clicked on: " + wordBlock.getWord().getWord());
                            // Handle double-click action, like editing
                            break;
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
        };

        addMouseListener(mouseAdapter);
        addMouseMotionListener(new MouseMotionAdapter() {
            @Override
            public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) {
                if (draggedWordBlock != null && lastDragPoint != null) {
                    int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x;
                    int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y;
                    Shape shape = wordBlockShapes.get(draggedWordBlock);
                    if (shape instanceof RoundRectangle2D) {
                        RoundRectangle2D rect = (RoundRectangle2D) shape;
                        rect.setFrame(rect.getX() + dx, rect.getY() + dy, rect.getWidth(), rect.getHeight());
                    }
                    lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();
                    repaint();
                }
            }
        });
    }

    public void addWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) {
        RoundRectangle2D roundRect = new RoundRectangle2D.Double(
            wordBlock.getPosition().x, wordBlock.getPosition().y, 100, 50, 10, 10);
        wordBlockShapes.put(wordBlock, roundRect);
    }

    public void clearWordBlocks() {
        wordBlockShapes.clear();
        repaint();
    }

    @Override
    protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
        super.paintComponent(g);
        Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g;
        for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
            WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey();
            Shape shape = entry.getValue();
            g2.setColor(getColorForWordBlock(wordBlock));
            g2.fill(shape);

            g2.setColor(Color.BLACK); // Text color
            g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20);
            g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40);
        }
    }

    private Color getColorForWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) {
        // Dummy implementation, replace with actual logic
        return switch (wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech()) {
            case NOUN -> Color.BLUE;
            case VERB -> Color.RED;
            // Add cases for other parts of speech
            default -> Color.GRAY;
        };
    }
}

In this updated WorkSpacePanel:

  • The wordBlockShapes map now stores Shape objects (RoundRectangle2D) instead of Rectangle to allow for rounded rectangles.
  • The mouseClicked method in MouseAdapter checks for double-clicks and logs the double-clicked WordBlock.
  • In paintComponent, Graphics2D is used to draw rounded rectangles and text for each WordBlock.
  • The text of the word and its part of speech is drawn within each shape.

This approach allows for visual interaction with WordBlock elements, providing visual feedback on hover and supporting double-click actions for further interaction.

You
Please extract the wordBankPanel to its own class like WorkSpacePanel: package LinguaLink; import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock; import LinguaLink.logger.Logger; import LinguaLink.components.word.PartOfSpeech; import LinguaLink.components.word.Word; import LinguaLink.guiComponents.ComplexCellRenderer; import LinguaLink.guiComponents.workSpacePanel.WorkSpacePanel; import javax.swing.*; import java.awt.*; import java.awt.event.MouseAdapter; import java.awt.event.MouseEvent; import java.util.List; public class App extends JFrame implements ModelObserver { private Model model; private Controller controller; private JPanel wordBankPanel; private WorkSpacePanel workSpacePanel; private DefaultListModel<Word> wordListRender; public App() { super("Interactive Language Learning Tool"); model = Model.getInstance(); model.addObserver(this); controller = Controller.getInstance(); initUI(); } private void initUI() { setupMenuBar(); setupMainAndSideLayout(); setSize(1920, 1080); setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE); } private void setupMenuBar() { JMenuBar menuBar = new JMenuBar(); JMenu fileMenu = new JMenu("File"); JMenuItem saveItem = new JMenuItem("Save"); fileMenu.add(saveItem); JMenuItem loadItem = new JMenuItem("Load"); fileMenu.add(loadItem); fileMenu.add(new JSeparator()); JMenuItem exportItem = new JMenuItem("Export"); fileMenu.add(exportItem); fileMenu.add(new JSeparator()); JMenuItem exitItem = new JMenuItem("Exit"); exitItem.addActionListener(e -> System.exit(0)); fileMenu.add(exitItem); menuBar.add(fileMenu); JMenu editMenu = new JMenu("Edit"); JMenuItem clearWordBank = new JMenuItem("Clear Word Bank"); clearWordBank.addActionListener(e -> { wordListRender.clear(); controller.clearWordBank(); Logger.info("WordBank cleared"); }); editMenu.add(clearWordBank); menuBar.add(editMenu); setJMenuBar(menuBar); } private JPanel constructWordBank() { wordBankPanel = new JPanel(); wordBankPanel.setLayout(new BorderLayout()); // Use BorderLayout for the entire panel // Upper panel with input fields and add button JPanel inputPanel = new JPanel(new FlowLayout()); // Create text input for word JTextField wordInput = new JTextField(20); // 20 columns width inputPanel.add(wordInput); // Create drop down with parts of speech JComboBox<PartOfSpeech> partsOfSpeechDropdown = new JComboBox<>(PartOfSpeech.values()); inputPanel.add(partsOfSpeechDropdown); // Create add button JButton addButton = new JButton("Add"); addButton.addActionListener(e -> { String wordText = wordInput.getText().trim(); PartOfSpeech selectedPos = (PartOfSpeech) partsOfSpeechDropdown.getSelectedItem(); if (!wordText.isEmpty()) { Word newWord = new Word(wordText, selectedPos); controller.addWordBankElement(newWord); wordInput.setText(""); // Clear input field } else { Logger.error("Empty word string could not be added to WordBank"); } }); inputPanel.add(addButton); // Create the word list model wordListRender = new DefaultListModel<>(); // Create the JList and set it to use the word list model JList<Word> wordList = new JList<>(wordListRender); wordList.setCellRenderer(new ComplexCellRenderer()); wordList.setSelectionMode(ListSelectionModel.SINGLE_SELECTION); wordList.addMouseListener(new MouseAdapter() { @Override public void mouseClicked(MouseEvent e) { if (e.getClickCount() == 2) { int index = wordList.locationToIndex(e.getPoint()); if (index >= 0) { Word selectedWord = wordList.getModel().getElementAt(index); controller.moveWordToWorkSpace(selectedWord); } } } }); // Add JList to a scroll pane (in case of many entries) JScrollPane listScroller = new JScrollPane(wordList); listScroller.setBorder(null); // Create a split pane to hold both the input panel and the list scroller JSplitPane splitPane = new JSplitPane( JSplitPane.VERTICAL_SPLIT, inputPanel, listScroller); splitPane.setResizeWeight(0); // The inputPanel area will not expand with the window size splitPane.setDividerLocation(75); // You can adjust this value as needed splitPane.setOneTouchExpandable(false); // Disable the one-touch expandable buttons splitPane.setEnabled(false); // Disable the divider so it can't be moved splitPane.setDividerSize(0); // Add the split pane to the wordBankPanel wordBankPanel.add(splitPane, BorderLayout.CENTER); return wordBankPanel; } private JPanel constructWorkSpace() { WorkSpacePanel workSpacePanel = new WorkSpacePanel(); for (WordBlock wordBlock : model.getWorkSpaceWordBlocks()) { workSpacePanel.addWordBlock(wordBlock); } return workSpacePanel; } private void setupMainAndSideLayout() { wordBankPanel = constructWordBank(); workSpacePanel = (WorkSpacePanel) constructWorkSpace(); JSplitPane splitPane = new JSplitPane(JSplitPane.HORIZONTAL_SPLIT, workSpacePanel, wordBankPanel); splitPane.setSize(1920, 1080); splitPane.setDividerLocation(0.8); splitPane.setOneTouchExpandable(false); // Disable the one-touch expandable buttons splitPane.setEnabled(false); // Disable the divider so it can't be moved splitPane.setDividerSize(0); getContentPane().add(splitPane, BorderLayout.CENTER); } @Override public void update() { // Refresh UI components based on the updated model refreshWordBank(); refreshWorkSpace(); } private void refreshWordBank() { List<Word> currentWords = model.getWordBankWords(); wordListRender.clear(); for (Word word : currentWords) { wordListRender.addElement(word); } Logger.info("WordBank updated."); } private void refreshWorkSpace() { workSpacePanel.clearWordBlocks(); // Clear existing WordBlocks for (WordBlock wordBlock : model.getWorkSpaceWordBlocks()) { workSpacePanel.addWordBlock(wordBlock); // Add WordBlocks from the model } workSpacePanel.repaint(); } public static void main(String[] args) { SwingUtilities.invokeLater(() -> new App().setVisible(true)); } }
ChatGPT

To refactor your constructWordBank method into its own class, follow these steps. You will create a new class called WordBankPanel which will encapsulate all the logic and UI elements of the word bank. This class will extend JPanel and can be used in your App class similarly to how you use WorkSpacePanel.

Here is how the WordBankPanel class can be implemented:

java
package LinguaLink.guiComponents;

import LinguaLink.components.word.PartOfSpeech;
import LinguaLink.components.word.Word;
import LinguaLink.logger.Logger;
import LinguaLink.Controller;

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.event.MouseAdapter;
import java.awt.event.MouseEvent;

public class WordBankPanel extends JPanel {
    private Controller controller;
    private DefaultListModel<Word> wordListModel;
    private JList<Word> wordList;

    public WordBankPanel(Controller controller) {
        this.controller = controller;
        this.setLayout(new BorderLayout());
        initializeUI();
    }

    private void initializeUI() {
        JPanel inputPanel = new JPanel(new FlowLayout());
        JTextField wordInput = new JTextField(20);
        JComboBox<PartOfSpeech> partsOfSpeechDropdown = new JComboBox<>(PartOfSpeech.values());
        JButton addButton = new JButton("Add");

        addButton.addActionListener(e -> {
            String wordText = wordInput.getText().trim();
            PartOfSpeech selectedPos = (PartOfSpeech) partsOfSpeechDropdown.getSelectedItem();
            if (!wordText.isEmpty()) {
                Word newWord = new Word(wordText, selectedPos);
                controller.addWordBankElement(newWord);
                wordInput.setText("");
            } else {
                Logger.error("Empty word string could not be added to WordBank");
            }
        });

        inputPanel.add(wordInput);
        inputPanel.add(partsOfSpeechDropdown);
        inputPanel.add(addButton);

        wordListModel = new DefaultListModel<>();
        wordList = new JList<>(wordListModel);
        wordList.setCellRenderer(new ComplexCellRenderer());
        wordList.setSelectionMode(ListSelectionModel.SINGLE_SELECTION);
        wordList.addMouseListener(new MouseAdapter() {
            @Override
            public void mouseClicked(MouseEvent e) {
                if (e.getClickCount() == 2) {
                    int index = wordList.locationToIndex(e.getPoint());
                    if (index >= 0) {
                        Word selectedWord = wordList.getModel().getElementAt(index);
                        controller.moveWordToWorkSpace(selectedWord);
                    }
                }
            }
        });

        JScrollPane listScroller = new JScrollPane(wordList);
        listScroller.setBorder(null);

        JSplitPane splitPane = new JSplitPane(
                JSplitPane.VERTICAL_SPLIT,
                inputPanel,
                listScroller);
        splitPane.setResizeWeight(0.1);
        splitPane.setDividerLocation(75);
        splitPane.setOneTouchExpandable(false);
        splitPane.setEnabled(false);
        splitPane.setDividerSize(0);

        this.add(splitPane, BorderLayout.CENTER);
    }

    public void refreshWordBank(List<Word> words) {
        wordListModel.clear();
        for (Word word : words) {
            wordListModel.addElement(word);
        }
    }
}

Now in your App class, you can use WordBankPanel like this:

java
private void setupMainAndSideLayout() {
    WordBankPanel wordBankPanel = new WordBankPanel(controller);
    workSpacePanel = new WorkSpacePanel();
    // Assuming you populate workspace in some other way

    JSplitPane splitPane = new JSplitPane(JSplitPane.HORIZONTAL_SPLIT, workSpacePanel, wordBankPanel);
    splitPane.setSize(1920, 1080);
    splitPane.setDividerLocation(0.8);
    splitPane.setOneTouchExpandable(false);
    splitPane.setEnabled(false);
    splitPane.setDividerSize(0);

    getContentPane().add(splitPane, BorderLayout.CENTER);
}

@Override
public void update() {
    List<Word> currentWords = model.getWordBankWords();
    wordBankPanel.refreshWordBank(currentWords);
    refreshWorkSpace();
}

This refactoring extracts the word bank functionality into its own class, making your App class cleaner and more focused. The WordBankPanel class now encapsulates all the behavior related to the word bank UI, including event handling and UI layout.

You
This is giving me the error for each not applicable for type Java.awt.List. public void refreshWordBank(List words) { wordListModel.clear(); for (Word word : words) { wordListModel.addElement(word); } }
ChatGPT

The error you're seeing suggests that there's a type mismatch, probably because the List in the refreshWordBank method is not properly parameterized. Java is treating it as a raw type, which can lead to type issues like the one you're encountering.

To ensure type safety and to avoid such errors, you should use generic types with your List. Specifically, the List should be parameterized with the Word type, assuming that's what you intend to iterate over.

Here’s how you can fix the refreshWordBank method:

java
public void refreshWordBank(List<Word> words) {
    wordListModel.clear();
    for (Word word : words) {
        wordListModel.addElement(word);
    }
}

By specifying List<Word>, you tell the Java compiler that the List contains Word objects, which makes the for-each loop valid for iterating over Word instances.

Make sure your import statements at the beginning of the file include the correct List class. It should be from the java.util package, not java.awt:

java
import java.util.List;

With these adjustments, the method should correctly iterate over the Word objects, and you should no longer see the type-related error.

You
Type 'java.awt.List' does not have type parameters
ChatGPT

The error message indicates that there is a confusion between java.awt.List and java.util.List. In Java, java.awt.List is a GUI component class that does not support generic type parameters, while java.util.List is a collection interface that does support generic types.

To resolve this issue, ensure you are importing the correct List type in your code. You should use java.util.List for a collection of objects. Here's how you should adjust the import statement at the top of your Java file:

java
import java.util.List; // Correct import for generic List

Here is the corrected method signature using java.util.List with generic type parameters, ensuring it can hold Word objects:

java
public void refreshWordBank(List<Word> words) {
    wordListModel.clear();
    for (Word word : words) {
        wordListModel.addElement(word);
    }
}

This method now correctly expects a List of Word objects as its parameter, allowing it to iterate through the Word objects and manipulate them as needed.

Make sure your import sections in your Java files do not mistakenly import java.awt.List when you intend to use collections.

You

for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey(); Shape shape = entry.getValue(); g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.fill(shape); g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); // Text color g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40); } } }
ChatGPT

To add a popup menu that appears when you right-click on the WordBlock objects in your WorkSpacePanel, you can create a JPopupMenu and show it during the appropriate mouse event. Here’s how you can implement this:

  1. Define a JPopupMenu and its menu items.
  2. Show this popup menu when a right-click is detected on a WordBlock.

Here's how you can extend the WorkSpacePanel class to include this functionality:

java
import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.event.MouseAdapter;
import java.awt.event.MouseEvent;
import java.awt.geom.RoundRectangle2D;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

public class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel {
    private Map<WordBlock, Shape> wordBlockShapes = new HashMap<>();
    private WordBlock selectedWordBlock; // Track the selected WordBlock
    private Controller controller;

    public WorkSpacePanel() {
        controller = Controller.getInstance();
        setBackground(Color.WHITE);
        setupMouseHandling();
        createPopupMenu();
    }

    private void createPopupMenu() {
        JPopupMenu popupMenu = new JPopupMenu();

        JMenuItem moveToBankItem = new JMenuItem("Move to Word Bank");
        moveToBankItem.addActionListener(e -> {
            if (selectedWordBlock != null) {
                controller.moveWordToWordBank(selectedWordBlock);
                wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock);
                repaint();
            }
        });

        JMenuItem deleteItem = new JMenuItem("Delete");
        deleteItem.addActionListener(e -> {
            if (selectedWordBlock != null) {
                wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock);
                repaint();
            }
        });

        popupMenu.add(moveToBankItem);
        popupMenu.add(deleteItem);

        addMouseListener(new MouseAdapter() {
            public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
                if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) {
                    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
                        if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
                            selectedWordBlock = entry.getKey();
                            popupMenu.show(e.getComponent(), e.getX(), e.getY());
                            return;
                        }
                    }
                    selectedWordBlock = null; // Clear selection if click outside any block
                }
            }
        });
    }

    private void setupMouseHandling() {
        // Your existing mouse handling logic...
    }

    // Your existing methods...
}

In this implementation:

  • selectedWordBlock is used to keep track of which WordBlock is currently under the right-click.
  • createPopupMenu() method creates the popup menu and defines actions for each menu item, such as moving the WordBlock back to the word bank or deleting it.
  • In the mousePressed method within createPopupMenu(), check if the right mouse button is pressed and show the popup menu if the click is on a WordBlock.

This setup allows users to right-click on WordBlock objects and select actions from the context menu, which can trigger appropriate behavior defined in your controller. Adjust and expand upon this functionality as needed for your application's requirements.

You
Can I paint a blue highlight around the selectedWordBlock block? package LinguaLink.guiComponents.workSpacePanel; import LinguaLink.Controller; import LinguaLink.Util; import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock; import LinguaLink.logger.Logger; import javax.swing.*; import java.awt.*; import java.awt.event.MouseAdapter; import java.awt.event.MouseEvent; import java.awt.event.MouseMotionAdapter; import java.awt.geom.RoundRectangle2D; import java.util.HashMap; import java.util.Map; public class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel { private Map<WordBlock, Shape> wordBlockShapes = new HashMap<>(); private WordBlock draggedWordBlock; private Point lastDragPoint; private Controller controller; private WordBlock selectedWordBlock; public WorkSpacePanel() { controller = Controller.getInstance(); setBackground(Color.WHITE); setupMouseHandling(); createPopupMenu(); } private void setupMouseHandling() { MouseAdapter mouseAdapter = new MouseAdapter() { @Override public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) { for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) { draggedWordBlock = entry.getKey(); lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); break; } } } @Override public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e) { draggedWordBlock = null; lastDragPoint = null; } @Override public void mouseClicked(MouseEvent e) { if (e.getClickCount() == 2) { for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) { WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey(); controller.moveWordToWordBank(wordBlock); break; } } } } }; addMouseListener(mouseAdapter); addMouseMotionListener(new MouseMotionAdapter() { @Override public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) { if (draggedWordBlock != null && lastDragPoint != null) { int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x; int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y; Shape shape = wordBlockShapes.get(draggedWordBlock); if (shape instanceof RoundRectangle2D) { RoundRectangle2D rect = (RoundRectangle2D) shape; rect.setFrame(rect.getX() + dx, rect.getY() + dy, rect.getWidth(), rect.getHeight()); } lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); controller.setWordBlockPosition(draggedWordBlock, dx, dy); repaint(); } } }); addMouseListener(new MouseAdapter() { public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) { if (SwingUtilities.isLeftMouseButton(e)) { for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) { selectedWordBlock = entry.getKey(); return; } } selectedWordBlock = null; } } }); } private void createPopupMenu() { JPopupMenu popupMenu = new JPopupMenu(); JMenuItem moveToBankItem = new JMenuItem("Move to Word Bank"); moveToBankItem.addActionListener(e -> { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { controller.moveWordToWordBank(selectedWordBlock); wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock); repaint(); } }); JMenuItem deleteItem = new JMenuItem("Delete"); deleteItem.addActionListener(e -> { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock); controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock); repaint(); } }); popupMenu.add(moveToBankItem); popupMenu.add(deleteItem); addMouseListener(new MouseAdapter() { public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) { if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) { for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) { selectedWordBlock = entry.getKey(); popupMenu.show(e.getComponent(), e.getX(), e.getY()); return; } } selectedWordBlock = null; // Clear selection if click outside any block } } }); } public void addWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) { RoundRectangle2D roundRect = new RoundRectangle2D.Double( wordBlock.getPosition().x, wordBlock.getPosition().y, 100, 50, 10, 10); wordBlockShapes.put(wordBlock, roundRect); } public void clearWordBlocks() { wordBlockShapes.clear(); repaint(); } @Override protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) { super.paintComponent(g); Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g; for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey(); Shape shape = entry.getValue(); g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.fill(shape); g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); // Text color g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40); } } }
ChatGPT

To paint a blue highlight around the selectedWordBlock, you can modify the paintComponent method to check if a WordBlock is the selected one and then draw a border around it. Here's how you can do this:

  1. Check if the current WordBlock in the iteration is the selectedWordBlock.
  2. If it is, draw a highlighted border around it.

Here's the updated paintComponent method with the highlighted border:

java
@Override
protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
    super.paintComponent(g);
    Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g;
    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
        WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey();
        Shape shape = entry.getValue();

        // Fill the shape with its background color
        g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech()));
        g2.fill(shape);

        // Draw text inside the shape
        g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech()));
        g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20);
        g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40);

        // If this is the selected word block, draw a highlight border around it
        if (wordBlock == selectedWordBlock) {
            g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2)); // Set stroke width for the highlight
            g2.setColor(Color.BLUE); // Highlight color
            g2.draw(shape); // Draw the highlight around the shape
        }
    }
}

In this code:

  • The paintComponent method iterates over each WordBlock and its associated shape.
  • Each shape is filled with its respective background color.
  • The text for the word and its part of speech is drawn inside the shape.
  • If the current WordBlock being drawn is the selectedWordBlock, a highlighted border is drawn around it using g2.draw(shape).
  • The color and stroke of the border can be adjusted to fit the visual style you want for the selection highlight.

This modification should provide a clear visual indication of which WordBlock is currently selected in the workspace.

You
And how would I get it to switch when the refresh function is called
ChatGPT

To switch the selection highlight when the refresh function is called in your WorkSpacePanel, you should manage the selection state and ensure it is updated correctly. Here's what you can do:

  1. Store the selected WordBlock in your WorkSpacePanel.
  2. Update the selection state as needed, for example, when a new WordBlock is clicked or when the workspace is refreshed.
  3. Redraw the panel to reflect the updated selection.

Assuming you already have a selectedWordBlock field and a method like refreshWorkSpace in your application, here's how you can manage the selection:

In WorkSpacePanel class

Add a method to set the selected WordBlock. This could be part of your mouse event handling or called externally:

java
public void setSelectedWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) {
    this.selectedWordBlock = wordBlock;
    repaint(); // Repaint to show the new selection immediately
}

In your refresh logic

When you call refreshWorkSpace in your App class (or wherever you manage the workspace updating), make sure to also manage the selection state. If you want to clear the selection when the workspace is refreshed, you could do something like this:

java
private void refreshWorkSpace() {
    // Assuming you have a method to get the current workspace word blocks
    List<WordBlock> workspaceWordBlocks = model.getWorkSpaceWordBlocks();

    workSpacePanel.clearWordBlocks(); // Clear the existing word blocks on the panel

    for (WordBlock wordBlock : workspaceWordBlocks) {
        workSpacePanel.addWordBlock(wordBlock); // Re-add word blocks from the model
    }

    workSpacePanel.setSelectedWordBlock(null); // Clear or update the selection
    workSpacePanel.repaint(); // Repaint to update the view
}

Selection Logic

Ensure that when you set the selection, it's meaningful in the context of your application's state. For instance, if you are refreshing the workspace and still want to keep a particular WordBlock selected (if it still exists after the refresh), you would need to pass that WordBlock to setSelectedWordBlock instead of null.

The call to repaint() inside setSelectedWordBlock will ensure the WorkSpacePanel is updated to reflect the new selection state.

By managing the selected WordBlock like this, your workspace should be able to show the selected state dynamically, updating appropriately when the model changes or when user interactions occur.

This isn't working the way I want it to. Please fix it so that I can click the workspace background (any space that's not a WordBlock) it will set selectedWordBlock to null and not highlight any WordBlock. package LinguaLink.guiComponents.workSpacePanel; import LinguaLink.Controller; import LinguaLink.Util; import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock; import LinguaLink.logger.Logger; import javax.swing.*; import java.awt.*; import java.awt.event.MouseAdapter; import java.awt.event.MouseEvent; import java.awt.event.MouseMotionAdapter; import java.awt.geom.RoundRectangle2D; import java.util.HashMap; import java.util.Map; public class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel { private Map<WordBlock, Shape> wordBlockShapes = new HashMap<>(); return; } } selectedWordBlock = null; } } }); } private void createPopupMenu() { JPopupMenu popupMenu = new JPopupMenu(); JMenuItem moveToBankItem = new JMenuItem("Move to Word Bank"); moveToBankItem.addActionListener(e -> { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { controller.moveWordToWordBank(selectedWordBlock); controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock); repaint(); } }); popupMenu.add(moveToBankItem); popupMenu.add(deleteItem); addMouseListener(new MouseAdapter() { public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) { if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) { for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) { selectedWordBlock = entry.getKey(); g2.fill(shape); // Draw text inside the shape g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20); ChatGPT

To ensure that selectedWordBlock is set to null when clicking on the background of the WorkSpacePanel (any space not occupied by a WordBlock), you need to adjust the mouse handling logic. Specifically, you should check whether the mouse click occurs inside any WordBlock bounds and, if not, clear the selection.

You currently have overlapping addMouseListener calls in the setupMouseHandling method, which complicates the logic. Let's consolidate these into a single mouse listener and handle both the selection and the popup menu logic there.

Here is how you can adjust the setupMouseHandling method:

java
private void setupMouseHandling() {
    MouseAdapter mouseAdapter = new MouseAdapter() {
        @Override
        public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
            boolean clickedOnBlock = false;
            for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
                if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
                    clickedOnBlock = true;
                    draggedWordBlock = entry.getKey();
                    selectedWordBlock = entry.getKey();
                    lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();

                    // Show the popup menu on right click
                    if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) {
                        createPopupMenu().show(e.getComponent(), e.getX(), e.getY());
                    }
                    break;
                }
            }

            if (!clickedOnBlock) {
                selectedWordBlock = null;
                if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) {
                    // Optionally show a general context menu for the workspace panel
                    // createGeneralPopupMenu().show(e.getComponent(), e.getX(), e.getY());
                }
            }

            repaint(); // Repaint to update the selection highlight
        }

        @Override
        public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e) {
            draggedWordBlock = null;
            lastDragPoint = null;
        }

        @Override
        public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) {
            if (draggedWordBlock != null && lastDragPoint != null) {
                int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x;
                int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y;
                Shape shape = wordBlockShapes.get(draggedWordBlock);
                if (shape instanceof RoundRectangle2D) {
                    RoundRectangle2D rect = (RoundRectangle2D) shape;
                    rect.setFrame(rect.getX() + dx, rect.getY() + dy, rect.getWidth(), rect.getHeight());
                }
                lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();

                controller.setWordBlockPosition(draggedWordBlock, dx, dy);

                repaint();
            }
        }
    };

    addMouseListener(mouseAdapter);
    addMouseMotionListener(mouseAdapter); // Use the same adapter for motion events
}

private JPopupMenu createPopupMenu() {
    JPopupMenu popupMenu = new JPopupMenu();

    JMenuItem moveToBankItem = new JMenuItem("Move to Word Bank");
    moveToBankItem.addActionListener(e -> {
        if (selectedWordBlock != null) {
            controller.moveWordToWordBank(selectedWordBlock);
            wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock);
            repaint();
        }
    });

    JMenuItem deleteItem = new JMenuItem("Delete");
    deleteItem.addActionListener(e -> {
        if (selectedWordBlock != null) {
            wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock);
            controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock);
            selectedWordBlock = null; // Clear selection after deletion
            repaint();
        }
    });

    popupMenu.add(moveToBankItem);
    popupMenu.add(deleteItem);

    return popupMenu;
}

In this revised setup:

  • A single MouseAdapter handles both dragging and clicking logic.
  • The selectedWordBlock is updated within the mousePressed method based on whether a WordBlock is clicked or not.
  • The popup menu is shown if the right-click is on a WordBlock.
  • The workspace is repainted when necessary to update the highlight around the selected WordBlock.
  • The popup menu creation is moved into a separate createPopupMenu method for clarity and to prevent multiple popup menus from being created unnecessarily.

This approach ensures that clicking on the background of the WorkSpacePanel will clear the selectedWordBlock and remove any highlights, providing a clearer and more intuitive user experience.

You
Additionally modify this class to delete the selected wordBlock if I press the delete key.
ChatGPT

To allow deleting the selected WordBlock when the delete key is pressed, you need to add key event handling to the WorkSpacePanel. In Swing, adding key event listeners to a JPanel can be a bit tricky because JPanel does not receive key events by default. You need to make it focusable and set a key listener. Here's how you can do it:

  1. Make the WorkSpacePanel focusable so it can receive key events.
  2. Add a key listener to handle the delete key press.

Here's the updated WorkSpacePanel class with key event handling for deleting the selected WordBlock:

java
package LinguaLink.guiComponents.workSpacePanel;

import LinguaLink.Controller;
import LinguaLink.Util;
import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock;
import LinguaLink.logger.Logger;

import javax.swing.*;
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.event.*;
import java.awt.geom.RoundRectangle2D;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

public class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel {
    private Map<WordBlock, Shape> wordBlockShapes = new HashMap<>();
    private WordBlock draggedWordBlock;
    private Point lastDragPoint;
    private Controller controller;
    private WordBlock selectedWordBlock;

    public WorkSpacePanel() {
        controller = Controller.getInstance();
        setBackground(Color.WHITE);
        setFocusable(true); // Make the panel focusable to receive key events
        setupMouseHandling();
        setupKeyHandling();
        createPopupMenu();
    }

    private void setupMouseHandling() {
        // Your existing mouse handling setup
    }

    private void setupKeyHandling() {
        addKeyListener(new KeyAdapter() {
            @Override
            public void keyPressed(KeyEvent e) {
                if (e.getKeyCode() == KeyEvent.VK_DELETE) {
                    if (selectedWordBlock != null) {
                        controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock);
                        wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock);
                        selectedWordBlock = null;
                        repaint();
                    }
                }
            }
        });
    }

    private JPopupMenu createPopupMenu() {
        // Your existing popup menu setup
    }

    // Your existing methods...

    @Override
    protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
        // Your existing painting code
    }
}

In this updated code:

  • setFocusable(true) makes the WorkSpacePanel capable of receiving keyboard input.
  • setupKeyHandling() adds a KeyListener to the panel, checking for the delete key (via KeyEvent.VK_DELETE) and performing the delete action if selectedWordBlock is not null.

Important Note: For key events to be received, the WorkSpacePanel must have focus. Ensure that the panel can gain focus when interacting with it (e.g., after clicking on it) to allow key event processing. You might need to manually request focus in the mouse event handler to ensure the panel can receive key events after interaction:

java
@Override
public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
    requestFocusInWindow(); // Request focus to ensure key events are received after clicking
    // existing mouse press handling logic...
}

This modification enables the deletion of the selected WordBlock using the delete key, integrating keyboard interaction into the WorkSpacePanel functionality.

You
This isn't working, I placed a print statement inside of the keyPressed event, but I don't see any output package LinguaLink.guiComponents.workSpacePanel; import LinguaLink.Controller; import LinguaLink.Util; import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock; import LinguaLink.logger.Logger; import javax.swing.*; import java.awt.*; import java.awt.event.*; import java.awt.geom.RoundRectangle2D; import java.util.HashMap; } lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); controller.setWordBlockPosition(draggedWordBlock, dx, dy); repaint(); } } }; addMouseListener(mouseAdapter); addMouseMotionListener(mouseAdapter); // Use the same adapter for motion events } private JPopupMenu createPopupMenu() { JPopupMenu popupMenu = new JPopupMenu(); JMenuItem moveToBankItem = new JMenuItem("Move to Word Bank"); moveToBankItem.addActionListener(e -> { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { controller.moveWordToWordBank(selectedWordBlock); wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock); repaint(); } }); JMenuItem deleteItem = new JMenuItem("Delete"); deleteItem.addActionListener(e -> { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock); controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock); selectedWordBlock = null; // Clear selection after deletion repaint(); } }); popupMenu.add(moveToBankItem); popupMenu.add(deleteItem); return popupMenu; } public void addWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) { RoundRectangle2D roundRect = new RoundRectangle2D.Double( wordBlock.getPosition().x, wordBlock.getPosition().y, 100, 50, 10, 10); wordBlockShapes.put(wordBlock, roundRect); } public void clearWordBlocks() { wordBlockShapes.clear(); repaint(); } @Override protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) { super.paintComponent(g); Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g; for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey(); Shape shape = entry.getValue(); // Fill the shape with its background color g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.fill(shape); // Draw text inside the shape g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40); // If this is the selected word block, draw a highlight border around it if (wordBlock == selectedWordBlock) { g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2)); // Set stroke width for the highlight g2.setColor(Color.BLUE); // Highlight color g2.draw(shape); // Draw the highlight around the shape } } } }
ChatGPT

In Swing, JPanel doesn't normally handle key events because it doesn't have keyboard focus by default. To handle key events, you need to make sure the panel can gain focus and then actively request focus when it's appropriate. Additionally, in complex UIs, using KeyBindings is preferred over KeyListeners because KeyListeners require the component to have focus to work, and managing focus can be tricky in Swing.

Let's address these points to fix the handling of the delete key in WorkSpacePanel.

  1. Request focus on mouse press: This ensures the panel can receive key events after being interacted with.

  2. Use Key Bindings instead of Key Listener: Key Bindings allow you to define how a component reacts to key strokes even if it doesn't have focus, as long as the window does.

Here's how you can implement these changes:

Update setupMouseHandling method

java
private void setupMouseHandling() {
    MouseAdapter mouseAdapter = new MouseAdapter() {
        @Override
        public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
            requestFocusInWindow();  // Request focus to handle key events
            boolean clickedOnBlock = false;
            for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
                if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
                    clickedOnBlock = true;
                    draggedWordBlock = entry.getKey();
                    selectedWordBlock = entry.getKey();
                    lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();

                    if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) {
                        createPopupMenu().show(e.getComponent(), e.getX(), e.getY());
                    }
                    break;
                }
            }

            if (!clickedOnBlock) {
                selectedWordBlock = null;
            }

            repaint();
        }

        @Override
        public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e) {
            draggedWordBlock = null;
            lastDragPoint = null;
        }

        @Override
        public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) {
            if (draggedWordBlock != null && lastDragPoint != null) {
                int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x;
                int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y;
                Shape shape = wordBlockShapes.get(draggedWordBlock);
                if (shape instanceof RoundRectangle2D) {
                    RoundRectangle2D rect = (RoundRectangle2D) shape;
                    rect.setFrame(rect.getX() + dx, rect.getY() + dy, rect.getWidth(), rect.getHeight());
                }
                lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();
                controller.setWordBlockPosition(draggedWordBlock, dx, dy);
                repaint();
            }
        }
    };

    addMouseListener(mouseAdapter);
    addMouseMotionListener(mouseAdapter);
}

Setup Key Bindings in the constructor

java
public WorkSpacePanel() {
    controller = Controller.getInstance();
    setBackground(Color.WHITE);
    setFocusable(true);
    setupMouseHandling();
    setupKeyBindings();
    createPopupMenu();
}

private void setupKeyBindings() {
    getInputMap(JComponent.WHEN_IN_FOCUSED_WINDOW).put(KeyStroke.getKeyStroke(KeyEvent.VK_DELETE, 0), "DeleteWordBlock");
    getActionMap().put("DeleteWordBlock", new AbstractAction() {
        @Override
        public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
            if (selectedWordBlock != null) {
                controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock);
                wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock);
                selectedWordBlock = null;
                repaint();
            }
        }
    });
}

In this setup:

  • requestFocusInWindow() is called within mousePressed to ensure the WorkSpacePanel can receive key events.
  • Key bindings are set up to listen for the Delete key. When pressed, it performs the action to delete the selectedWordBlock if one is selected.

This approach should reliably handle the delete key across the entire window without needing the WorkSpacePanel to be explicitly focused, as key bindings are more flexible and robust in handling keyboard interactions in Swing applications.

You
Its still not working, I'm not seeing anything, I would just like to detect a delete press no matter what, then delete the active word block if its not null
ChatGPT

To ensure that you can detect a delete key press no matter what and act upon it (like deleting the active WordBlock if it's not null), you should ensure that your Swing application is properly set up to listen for keyboard events. Given the scenario where you want to listen for global key presses, you should consider focusing on the top-level window or using global key event listeners that are active regardless of which component has the focus.

However, in a standard Swing application, components like JPanel do not receive key events unless they are focusable and have the focus. Since making a JPanel focusable and ensuring it retains focus in a complex UI can be challenging, another approach is to use the key bindings at the JFrame level or utilize a toolkit to add a global keyboard listener.

Since you want a solution that works no matter what, let's simplify the approach to ensure functionality:

  1. Ensure your JFrame (the main window) is listening for key events. This way, regardless of which component has the focus, the JFrame can handle the delete key press.

  2. Use the Key Bindings or Toolkit for global shortcuts if necessary.

If the above approach still doesn't work because of focus issues or other complexities in the Swing event handling, here's another way to globally detect key presses in a Swing application using the AWT Toolkit. This is not the usual way to handle key events in Swing and should be used cautiously because it's more like setting up a global shortcut listener:

java
Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().addAWTEventListener(new AWTEventListener() {
    public void eventDispatched(AWTEvent event) {
        if (event instanceof KeyEvent) {
            KeyEvent ke = (KeyEvent) event;
            if (ke.getID() == KeyEvent.KEY_PRESSED && ke.getKeyCode() == KeyEvent.VK_DELETE) {
                SwingUtilities.invokeLater(() -> {
                    if (selectedWordBlock != null) {
                        // Perform deletion or whatever action you need
                        System.out.println("Delete key pressed and action performed.");
                        controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock);
                        wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock);
                        selectedWordBlock = null;
                        repaint();
                    }
                });
            }
        }
    }
}, AWTEvent.KEY_EVENT_MASK);

You can place this in the initialization code of your application to ensure it's set up when the program starts.

Note:

  • This listener will listen to all key events in the application, not just in the specific panel, so be cautious as it can lead to unexpected behavior if not handled properly.
  • The use of SwingUtilities.invokeLater() is to ensure that the GUI update code is executed in the Event Dispatch Thread, which is the proper way to update GUI components in Swing.

Lastly, ensure that there's logic to manage the lifecycle of this global listener appropriately, removing it when not needed anymore to avoid memory leaks or unwanted behavior.

You
So what is the typical way to do this. I just want to be able to select wordBlocks in the WorkSpace and delete them by pressing backspace (i'm on macbook) or delete
ChatGPT

The typical way to handle key events for specific actions like deleting an item in a Swing application is through the use of key bindings. Key bindings allow you to define how a component reacts to key strokes without requiring the component to have keyboard focus, which makes them more flexible than key listeners.

In the case of the WorkSpacePanel where you want to delete a selected WordBlock using the Backspace or Delete key, you should use key bindings on the panel. However, for key bindings to work, the component needs to be able to gain focus. Since JPanel is not focusable by default, you need to make it focusable and then request focus when appropriate, typically after an interaction like a mouse click.

Here’s how you can implement it in WorkSpacePanel:

  1. Make WorkSpacePanel focusable.
  2. Use key bindings to handle Backspace and Delete keys.
  3. Request focus in the panel during mouse interaction to ensure key events are caught.

Making WorkSpacePanel focusable

In your constructor for WorkSpacePanel, add:

java
setFocusable(true);

Setting up key bindings

In your setupKeyHandling method or directly in the constructor of WorkSpacePanel, you can add:

java
private void setupKeyHandling() {
    // KeyStroke.getKeyStroke takes the key constant and an optional modifier (like shift, ctrl, etc.)
    InputMap inputMap = getInputMap(WHEN_IN_FOCUSED_WINDOW); // Use WHEN_FOCUSED if only this panel should react
    ActionMap actionMap = getActionMap();

    inputMap.put(KeyStroke.getKeyStroke(KeyEvent.VK_DELETE, 0), "DeleteBlock");
    inputMap.put(KeyStroke.getKeyStroke(KeyEvent.VK_BACK_SPACE, 0), "DeleteBlock");

    actionMap.put("DeleteBlock", new AbstractAction() {
        @Override
        public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
            if (selectedWordBlock != null) {
                controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock);
                wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock);
                selectedWordBlock = null;
                repaint();
            }
        }
    });
}

Request focus on interaction

In your mouse listener where you select WordBlock:

java
public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
    requestFocusInWindow(); // Make sure we can catch key events after clicking
    // existing selection logic...
}

Integrating the setup

Ensure setupKeyHandling() is called in the WorkSpacePanel constructor after setFocusable(true);.

By following this typical approach with key bindings, you make the component react to key strokes when it has focus. Since you're using WHEN_IN_FOCUSED_WINDOW, it will respond to the events even if it's not the direct focus owner, as long as the window is focused. This is generally how keyboard interactions are managed in Swing applications for specific component actions like deleting an item.
