You
How can I add a floating button at the bottom of the workspace with text 'Default' and define a handler?
ChatGPT

To add a floating button at the bottom of the workspace in a Swing application, you can use layout managers effectively to position the button. For a floating button, you typically want it to appear above other components, not obstructed or aligned strictly to the container's border. However, "floating" in a strict sense as in web development (CSS) is not native to Swing. Instead, you position components using layout managers or by setting bounds directly for absolute positioning.

Assuming by "floating" you mean a button that stays visually distinct and positioned at a specific location (like at the bottom of the panel), you can use a combination of layouts to achieve this. Here's how you can do it in your WorkSpacePanel:

  1. Use a BorderLayout for the WorkSpacePanel.
  2. Add the drawing area (for word blocks) to the center.
  3. Add the button to the bottom (south area of the BorderLayout).

Here's an example of how you could implement this in your WorkSpacePanel class:

java
public class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel {
    private Controller controller;
    private JButton defaultButton;

    public WorkSpacePanel() {
        super(new BorderLayout()); // Use BorderLayout for this panel
        controller = Controller.getInstance();
        setupWorkspaceArea();
        setupDefaultButton();
    }

    private void setupWorkspaceArea() {
        JPanel drawingArea = new JPanel(); // Or another suitable component/class for drawing
        drawingArea.setBackground(Color.WHITE);
        add(drawingArea, BorderLayout.CENTER); // Add drawing area to the center
    }

    private void setupDefaultButton() {
        defaultButton = new JButton("Default");
        defaultButton.addActionListener(e -> handleDefaultButtonClick());

        // Create a panel to hold the button and give some padding
        JPanel buttonPanel = new JPanel();
        buttonPanel.setLayout(new FlowLayout(FlowLayout.RIGHT)); // Align the button to the right
        buttonPanel.add(defaultButton);

        add(buttonPanel, BorderLayout.SOUTH); // Add to the bottom of the WorkSpacePanel
    }

    private void handleDefaultButtonClick() {
        // Handler code for the button click
        System.out.println("Default button clicked");
    }
}

In this setup:

  • WorkSpacePanel uses a BorderLayout.
  • The central area (assigned to BorderLayout.CENTER) is intended for your word blocks or whatever your workspace consists of.
  • The "Default" button is added to a small panel that's then placed in the BorderLayout.SOUTH area, making it appear at the bottom.
  • The button's action listener invokes handleDefaultButtonClick, where you can define what happens when the button is clicked.

This approach places the button at the bottom of the workspace panel, effectively making it a fixed UI element within that context. Adjust styling, padding, or layout as needed to match your UI design requirements.

You
Lets come back to the button. I want to be able to draw a line between two WordBlocks (representing a grammatical connection between them). What is the simplest way I could just get this feature up and running. I would think something like selecting a wordBlock, then shift clicking some other word block. This would create a Connection object between them and update the model as appropriate. The WorkSpace component would render these connections as line between the word blocks.
ChatGPT

To implement the feature where you can draw a line between two WordBlock objects to represent a grammatical connection, you can follow these steps:

  1. Track selected WordBlock objects: Keep track of the first and second selections.
  2. Handle shift-clicking: Detect if the user is shift-clicking to select the second WordBlock.
  3. Create a Connection object: Represent the line/connection between the two WordBlock objects.
  4. Update the model: Add the new connection to your model.
  5. Render the connections: Draw lines between connected WordBlock objects in the WorkSpacePanel.

Step 1: Define Necessary Variables

Add fields in your WorkSpacePanel class to keep track of selections and connections:

java
private WordBlock firstSelectedBlock;
private WordBlock secondSelectedBlock;
private List<Connection> connections = new ArrayList<>();

Step 2: Modify Mouse Handling

Modify your mousePressed method to handle shift-clicking:

java
@Override
public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
    requestFocusInWindow();
    WordBlock clickedBlock = null;
    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
        if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
            clickedBlock = entry.getKey();
            break;
        }
    }

    if (clickedBlock != null) {
        if (e.isShiftDown()) {
            if (firstSelectedBlock != null && clickedBlock != firstSelectedBlock) {
                secondSelectedBlock = clickedBlock;
                createConnection(firstSelectedBlock, secondSelectedBlock);
                firstSelectedBlock = null; // Reset after creating connection
                secondSelectedBlock = null;
            }
        } else {
            firstSelectedBlock = clickedBlock;
            selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // For highlighting or other actions
        }
    }

    repaint();
}

Step 3: Connection Handling

Define the createConnection method to update your model:

java
private void createConnection(WordBlock from, WordBlock to) {
    Connection newConnection = new Connection(from, to);
    connections.add(newConnection); // Assuming you have a way to handle these in your model
    controller.addConnection(newConnection); // Update the model through the controller
}

Step 4: Rendering Connections

Modify your paintComponent method to draw lines between connected WordBlock objects:

java
@Override
protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
    super.paintComponent(g);
    Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g;

    // Existing code to draw WordBlocks...

    // Draw connections
    g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));
    g2.setColor(Color.BLACK);
    for (Connection conn : connections) {
        Point fromPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getFrom()));
        Point toPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getTo()));
        g2.drawLine(fromPoint.x, fromPoint.y, toPoint.x, toPoint.y);
    }
}

private Point getCenterPoint(Shape shape) {
    Rectangle bounds = shape.getBounds();
    return new Point(bounds.x + bounds.width / 2, bounds.y + bounds.height / 2);
}

Step 5: Update Model and Controller

Ensure your Controller and model classes have methods to handle the addition of Connection objects. The model should store these connections and provide them to the WorkSpacePanel for rendering.

By following these steps, you'll have a basic implementation to create and display grammatical connections between WordBlock objects in your workspace by selecting them with a shift-click operation. Adjust and expand this logic according to your application's needs and data structure.

You
It can't resolve the name getCenterPoint()
ChatGPT

The getCenterPoint method is meant to calculate the center point of a given shape, which is used to draw lines between WordBlock objects. If it's not recognized, it means we need to define this method in your WorkSpacePanel class.

Here's how you can implement getCenterPoint in the WorkSpacePanel class:

java
private Point getCenterPoint(Shape shape) {
    Rectangle2D bounds = shape.getBounds2D(); // Use getBounds2D for more precise floating-point bounds
    int centerX = (int) bounds.getCenterX();
    int centerY = (int) bounds.getCenterY();
    return new Point(centerX, centerY);
}

This method calculates the center of the given shape (which is expected to be the bounding box of a WordBlock). getBounds2D() is used to get the bounding box of the shape, and getCenterX() and getCenterY() methods of Rectangle2D are used to find the central point of this rectangle.

You should add this method to your WorkSpacePanel class where you have the drawing logic and other methods related to handling the word blocks and their connections.

Now, whenever you call getCenterPoint(shape), it should return the Point object representing the center of the provided shape, which you can then use to draw lines or for other purposes in your rendering logic.

You
Exception in thread "AWT-EventQueue-0" java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "java.util.List.getClass()" because "list" is null at java.base/java.util.Collections.unmodifiableList(Collections.java:1473) at LinguaLink.containers.workspace.WorkSpace.getConnections(WorkSpace.java:36)
ChatGPT

The NullPointerException you're encountering indicates that you're trying to call a method (getClass() in the context of Collections.unmodifiableList) on a null object. In this case, it looks like the list you're trying to make unmodifiable in WorkSpace.getConnections() is null.

To resolve this issue, you need to ensure that the list you're working with is not null before you attempt to wrap it with Collections.unmodifiableList. Here’s how you can safely handle this:

Checking for null Before Usage

You should check if the list (in this context, probably the list of connections) is null before you try to use it in Collections.unmodifiableList. If it’s null, you should either initialize it or handle the null case appropriately.

Assuming getConnections() is meant to return a list of connections, you should ensure this method handles a null list safely:

java
public List<Connection> getConnections() {
    if (connections == null) {
        connections = new ArrayList<>();  // Initialize the list if it's null
    }
    return Collections.unmodifiableList(connections);
}

In this code, connections is checked for null, and if it is null, it's initialized to a new ArrayList<>() before being wrapped with Collections.unmodifiableList.

Ensuring Proper Initialization

Make sure that the list (connections in this case) is properly initialized when the WorkSpace object is created. This could be done in the constructor of WorkSpace or at the point of declaration:

java
private List<Connection> connections = new ArrayList<>();

By ensuring that connections is never null when it's accessed, you avoid NullPointerException.

Modifying the WorkSpace Class

Here is a revised approach to ensure that connections is always properly handled:

java
package LinguaLink.containers.workspace;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.Collections;
import java.util.List;

public class WorkSpace {
    private List<Connection> connections;

    public WorkSpace() {
        connections = new ArrayList<>();  // Ensure the list is initialized
    }

    public List<Connection> getConnections() {
        // No need to check for null here since we ensure it's initialized in the constructor
        return Collections.unmodifiableList(connections);
    }

    // Other methods...
}

By ensuring that connections is never null when getConnections() is called, you should avoid the NullPointerException.

import LinguaLink.components.connection.Connection; import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock; import LinguaLink.logger.Logger; import javax.swing.*; import java.awt.*; import java.awt.event.*; import java.awt.geom.Rectangle2D; import java.awt.geom.RoundRectangle2D; import java.util.HashMap; import java.util.Map; public class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel { private Map<WordBlock, Shape> wordBlockShapes = new HashMap<>(); } private void setupKeyHandling() { // KeyStroke.getKeyStroke takes the key constant and an optional modifier (like shift, ctrl, etc.) InputMap inputMap = getInputMap(WHEN_IN_FOCUSED_WINDOW); // Use WHEN_FOCUSED if only this panel should react ActionMap actionMap = getActionMap(); inputMap.put(KeyStroke.getKeyStroke(KeyEvent.VK_DELETE, 0), "DeleteBlock"); inputMap.put(KeyStroke.getKeyStroke(KeyEvent.VK_BACK_SPACE, 0), "DeleteBlock"); actionMap.put("DeleteBlock", new AbstractAction() { @Override public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock); createConnection(firstSelectedBlock, secondSelectedBlock); firstSelectedBlock = null; // Reset after creating connection secondSelectedBlock = null; } } else { firstSelectedBlock = clickedBlock; selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // For highlighting or other actions } } repaint(); } @Override public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e) { draggedWordBlock = null; lastDragPoint = null; } @Override public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) { if (draggedWordBlock != null && lastDragPoint != null) { int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x; int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y; Shape shape = wordBlockShapes.get(draggedWordBlock); if (shape instanceof RoundRectangle2D) { RoundRectangle2D rect = (RoundRectangle2D) shape; rect.setFrame(rect.getX() + dx, rect.getY() + dy, rect.getWidth(), rect.getHeight()); } lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); controller.setWordBlockPosition(draggedWordBlock, dx, dy); repaint(); } } }; addMouseListener(mouseAdapter); addMouseMotionListener(mouseAdapter); } private JPopupMenu createPopupMenu() { JPopupMenu popupMenu = new JPopupMenu(); JMenuItem moveToBankItem = new JMenuItem("Move to Word Bank"); moveToBankItem.addActionListener(e -> { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { controller.moveWordToWordBank(selectedWordBlock); wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock); repaint(); } }); JMenuItem deleteItem = new JMenuItem("Delete"); deleteItem.addActionListener(e -> { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock); controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock); selectedWordBlock = null; // Clear selection after deletion repaint(); } }); popupMenu.add(moveToBankItem); popupMenu.add(deleteItem); return popupMenu; } public void addWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) { RoundRectangle2D roundRect = new RoundRectangle2D.Double( wordBlock.getPosition().x, wordBlock.getPosition().y, 100, 50, 10, 10); wordBlockShapes.put(wordBlock, roundRect); } public void clearWordBlocks() { wordBlockShapes.clear(); repaint(); } @Override protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) { super.paintComponent(g); Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g; for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey(); Shape shape = entry.getValue(); // Fill the shape with its background color g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.fill(shape); // Draw text inside the shape g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40); // If this is the selected word block, draw a highlight border around it if (wordBlock == selectedWordBlock) { g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2)); // Set stroke width for the highlight g2.setColor(Color.BLUE); // Highlight color g2.draw(shape); // Draw the highlight around the shape } } // Draw connections g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2)); g2.setColor(Color.BLACK); for (Connection conn : model.getConnections()) { Point fromPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getFrom())); Point toPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getTo())); g2.drawLine(fromPoint.x, fromPoint.y, toPoint.x, toPoint.y); } } private void createConnection(WordBlock from, WordBlock to) { controller.addNewConnection(from, to); } private Point getCenterPoint(Shape shape) { Rectangle2D bounds = shape.getBounds2D(); int centerX = (int) bounds.getCenterX(); int centerY = (int) bounds.getCenterY(); return new Point(centerX, centerY); } }
ChatGPT

Based on the provided code, it seems the dragging functionality might not be working as intended because of how the draggedWordBlock is being managed. To ensure dragging works properly, you need to make sure that the draggedWordBlock is set correctly on mouse press and used effectively in the mouse drag logic.

Here are a few potential issues and solutions:

  1. draggedWordBlock Setup: Ensure draggedWordBlock is being set correctly when a mouse press is detected on a WordBlock.
  2. Consistency in Event Handling: You should maintain the state of which block is being dragged throughout the mouse drag operation.

Let’s refine the mouse event handling part, especially focusing on setting draggedWordBlock:

Fixing mousePressed and mouseDragged

In mousePressed, set draggedWordBlock when a block is clicked:

java
@Override
public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
    requestFocusInWindow(); // To ensure key events are received
    WordBlock clickedBlock = null;
    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
        Shape shape = entry.getValue();
        if (shape.contains(e.getPoint())) {
            clickedBlock = entry.getKey();
            break;
        }
    }

    if (clickedBlock != null) {
        if (e.isShiftDown() && firstSelectedBlock != null && clickedBlock != firstSelectedBlock) {
            secondSelectedBlock = clickedBlock;
            createConnection(firstSelectedBlock, secondSelectedBlock);
            firstSelectedBlock = null;
            secondSelectedBlock = null;
        } else {
            draggedWordBlock = clickedBlock;
            selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock;
        }
    } else {
        selectedWordBlock = null;
    }

    repaint();
}

@Override
public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) {
    if (draggedWordBlock != null) {
        int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x;
        int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y;

        // Assuming the shape being used to represent the position of WordBlocks is a Rectangle
        Shape shape = wordBlockShapes.get(draggedWordBlock);
        if (shape instanceof RoundRectangle2D) {
            RoundRectangle2D rect = (RoundRectangle2D) shape;
            rect.setFrame(rect.getX() + dx, rect.getY() + dy, rect.getWidth(), rect.getHeight());
        }

        lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();  // Update the last drag point

        controller.setWordBlockPosition(draggedWordBlock, rect.getX(), rect.getY());
        repaint();
    }
}

@Override
public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e) {
    draggedWordBlock = null;  // Clear the dragged block on release
    lastDragPoint = null;  // Clear the last drag point
}

Make sure lastDragPoint is updated correctly in mousePressed:

java
if (draggedWordBlock != null) {
    lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();  // Set initial drag point
}

With these changes:

  • draggedWordBlock is set when you press the mouse button on a WordBlock, and it’s used for dragging.
  • The drag operation updates the position of the draggedWordBlock continuously until the mouse button is released.
  • When not dragging (mouse released or clicking outside any WordBlock), draggedWordBlock is set to null.

These adjustments should allow you to drag each WordBlock smoothly.

You
how do I discard changes in git
ChatGPT

Discarding changes in Git depends on what exactly you want to discard and how those changes are recorded (e.g., untracked files, staged changes, or committed changes). Here are some common scenarios:

1. Discarding Unstaged Changes

If you have made changes to files that you haven't staged yet (i.e., you haven't run git add), you can discard these changes using:

bash
git checkout -- <file_path>

Or, for Git versions 2.23 and above, you can use the restore command:

bash
git restore <file_path>

To discard changes in all files in the working directory:

bash
git checkout -- .
# or
git restore .

2. Discarding Staged Changes

If you have staged changes (i.e., after running git add) but want to unstage them and discard the changes:

bash
git reset HEAD <file_path>  # To unstage
git checkout -- <file_path> # To discard changes

Or, using restore to handle both unstaging and discarding:

bash
git restore --source=HEAD --staged --worktree <file_path>

To discard changes in all staged files:

bash
git reset HEAD  # Unstages all changes
git checkout -- .  # Discards all changes in the working directory

3. Discarding Untracked Files

If you have untracked files (new files that haven’t been added to Git yet) and you want to remove them:

bash
git clean -f

To also remove untracked directories:

bash
git clean -fd

4. Discarding All Local Changes (Including Untracked Files)

To discard all local changes in your working directory, regardless of their state (including untracked files but excluding ignored files):

bash
git reset --hard HEAD
git clean -fd

5. Undoing Committed Changes

To undo committed changes, it's more about rewriting history or reverting to a previous state. If you just made a commit and want to undo it:

bash
git reset --hard HEAD~1  # Be cautious as this will rewrite history!

Important Notes

  • Be very careful when using git reset --hard or git clean as these commands can permanently delete your changes.
  • Always make sure you are in the correct branch and you've reviewed the changes you're discarding to avoid accidental data loss.
  • If you're unsure, it's a good idea to create a backup branch before discarding changes: git checkout -b backup-branch.

These are common commands to discard changes in Git, but the exact command to use can depend on your specific situation and what you're trying to achieve.

You
Implement the sinplest drawing of connections you can.
ChatGPT

To implement a simple way of drawing connections (lines) between selected WordBlock instances in your WorkSpacePanel, we'll keep it basic. We will:

  1. Select a WordBlock with a normal click.
  2. Select another WordBlock with a shift-click to create a connection.
  3. Draw lines between connected blocks.

Let's outline the simple approach step by step.

Step 1: Track Selected Blocks and Connections

In your WorkSpacePanel, you need variables to track selected blocks and a list to store the connections:

java
private WordBlock firstSelectedBlock;
private List<Connection> connections = new ArrayList<>();

Step 2: Update Mouse Handling

Modify the mousePressed method to select and connect WordBlock instances:

java
@Override
public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
    requestFocusInWindow();
    WordBlock clickedBlock = null;
    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
        if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
            clickedBlock = entry.getKey();
            break;
        }
    }

    if (clickedBlock != null) {
        if (e.isShiftDown() && firstSelectedBlock != null) {
            connections.add(new Connection(firstSelectedBlock, clickedBlock)); // Assume Connection is a suitable class
            firstSelectedBlock = null;  // Reset for the next connection
        } else {
            firstSelectedBlock = clickedBlock;
        }
    }

    repaint();
}

Step 3: Draw Connections

In the paintComponent method, draw lines for each connection:

java
@Override
protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
    super.paintComponent(g);
    Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g;

    // Draw WordBlocks...

    // Draw connections
    g2.setColor(Color.BLACK);  // Set line color
    for (Connection conn : connections) {
        Point fromPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getFrom()));
        Point toPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getTo()));
        g2.drawLine(fromPoint.x, fromPoint.y, toPoint.x, toPoint.y);
    }
}

Step 4: Define Connection and getCenterPoint

Ensure you have a Connection class that can hold two WordBlock objects (if not already defined), and implement getCenterPoint method to find the center of a shape:

java
public class Connection {
    private WordBlock from;
    private WordBlock to;

    public Connection(WordBlock from, WordBlock to) {
        this.from = from;
        this.to = to;
    }

    public WordBlock getFrom() {
        return from;
    }

    public WordBlock getTo() {
        return to;
    }
}

private Point getCenterPoint(Shape shape) {
    Rectangle2D bounds = shape.getBounds2D();
    return new Point((int) bounds.getCenterX(), (int) bounds.getCenterY());
}

This setup provides a basic mechanism for selecting WordBlock instances and visually representing connections between them. The mousePressed method updates the selection and connection state, while the paintComponent method handles the visual representation.

You
It must still maintain the logic that allows selecting and dragging. The above does not work with those features. @Override public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) { requestFocusInWindow(); WordBlock clickedBlock = null; boolean clickedOnBlock = false; for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) { clickedOnBlock = true; draggedWordBlock = entry.getKey(); selectedWordBlock = entry.getKey(); lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); // Show the popup menu on right click if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) { createPopupMenu().show(e.getComponent(), e.getX(), e.getY()); } break; } } if (!clickedOnBlock) { selectedWordBlock = null; if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) { // Optionally show a general context menu for the workspace panel // createGeneralPopupMenu().show(e.getComponent(), e.getX(), e.getY()); } } repaint(); // Repaint to update the selection highlight }
ChatGPT

To maintain the logic for selecting, dragging, and creating connections between WordBlock instances, you need to carefully handle the mouse events. Here's how you can manage this in the mousePressed method:

  1. Select and drag a WordBlock on normal mouse click and drag.
  2. Create a connection between two WordBlock instances on shift-click.
  3. Show popup menu on right-click.

Here’s the updated mousePressed method that incorporates these features:

java
@Override
public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
    requestFocusInWindow();
    WordBlock clickedBlock = null;
    boolean clickedOnBlock = false;
    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
        if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
            clickedBlock = entry.getKey();
            clickedOnBlock = true;
            lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();  // Set initial drag point

            if (e.isShiftDown()) {
                if (firstSelectedBlock != null && clickedBlock != firstSelectedBlock) {
                    connections.add(new Connection(firstSelectedBlock, clickedBlock));
                    firstSelectedBlock = null; // Reset for the next connection
                } else {
                    firstSelectedBlock = clickedBlock;
                }
            } else {
                draggedWordBlock = clickedBlock;
                selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock;
            }
            
            break;
        }
    }

    if (!clickedOnBlock && !e.isShiftDown()) {
        selectedWordBlock = null;
        firstSelectedBlock = null;  // Reset selection if we click on empty space without shift
    }

    if (!clickedOnBlock && SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) {
        createPopupMenu().show(this, e.getX(), e.getY());
    }

    repaint();  // Repaint to update the workspace
}

In this method:

  • When a block is clicked, it's set as draggedWordBlock and selectedWordBlock for dragging and showing selection, respectively.
  • If the shift key is down during the click and firstSelectedBlock is already set, a connection is created between firstSelectedBlock and the newly clicked block.
  • If the workspace is clicked without hitting a block and without holding shift, it clears the selection.
  • The right-click checks are outside the block-clicking logic to allow for context menu interactions anywhere on the panel.

This approach should maintain the functionality for selection, dragging, and creating connections, along with handling right-clicks for context menus.

ChatGPT

The error message indicates that there's a type mismatch when trying to use the show method of JPopupMenu. The show method expects a Component to anchor the popup menu and the x, y coordinates where the popup should appear. In your case, it seems like this is being misinterpreted inside the anonymous MouseAdapter class, leading to confusion about what this refers to.

To resolve this, you should specify WorkSpacePanel.this when you want to refer to the WorkSpacePanel instance from within the anonymous inner class, ensuring the correct reference is used:

java
if (!clickedOnBlock && SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) {
    createPopupMenu().show(WorkSpacePanel.this, e.getX(), e.getY());
}

In this context, WorkSpacePanel.this refers to the outer instance of the WorkSpacePanel class, not the anonymous MouseAdapter class. This way, you're passing the correct component reference to the show method of JPopupMenu, which should fix the type mismatch error.

ChatGPT

To address the issues with the popup menu not showing for each WordBlock and connections not being drawn, we need to make a few adjustments.

  1. Popup Menu Invocation: The popup menu should be invoked when right-clicking on a WordBlock, not when clicking outside of one.

  2. Drawing Connections: We need to ensure the connections are being drawn in the paintComponent method.

Here's how you can modify your mousePressed method and paintComponent method:

Adjusting mousePressed Method

You should show the popup menu when a WordBlock is right-clicked, and this logic should be inside the loop where you check if a WordBlock is clicked:

java
@Override
public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
    requestFocusInWindow();
    WordBlock clickedBlock = null;
    boolean clickedOnBlock = false;
    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
        if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
            clickedBlock = entry.getKey();
            clickedOnBlock = true;
            lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();  // Set initial drag point

            // Select or drag the block
            if (SwingUtilities.isLeftMouseButton(e)) {
                if (e.isShiftDown() && firstSelectedBlock != null && clickedBlock != firstSelectedBlock) {
                    connections.add(new Connection(firstSelectedBlock, clickedBlock));
                    firstSelectedBlock = null; // Reset for the next connection
                } else {
                    firstSelectedBlock = clickedBlock;
                    draggedWordBlock = clickedBlock;
                    selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // For highlighting or other actions
                }
            }

            // Show the popup menu on right click
            if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) {
                createPopupMenu().show(WorkSpacePanel.this, e.getX(), e.getY());
            }

            break;
        }
    }

    if (!clickedOnBlock) {
        selectedWordBlock = null;
        firstSelectedBlock = null;
        draggedWordBlock = null;
    }

    repaint();  // Repaint to update the workspace
}

Adjusting paintComponent Method

Ensure connections are being drawn by iterating over the connections list:

java
@Override
protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
    super.paintComponent(g);
    Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g;

    // Draw WordBlocks...
    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
        WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey();
        Shape shape = entry.getValue();
        g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech()));
        g2.fill(shape);

        g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech()));
        g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20);
        g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40);

        if (wordBlock == selectedWordBlock) {
            g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2));
            g2.setColor(Color.BLUE);
            g2.draw(shape);
        }
    }

    // Draw connections
    g2.setColor(Color.BLACK);
    for (Connection conn : connections) {
        Point fromPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getFrom()));
        Point toPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getTo()));
        g2.drawLine(fromPoint.x, fromPoint.y, toPoint.x, toPoint.y);
    }
}

These changes ensure that:

  • The popup menu is shown when right-clicking on a WordBlock.
  • Connections are properly drawn between WordBlock instances in the paintComponent method.

Also, the createPopupMenu method should ideally be called just once to initialize the menu, and not every time in the mousePressed method. You could store the JPopupMenu as a field and then just show it on right clicks to be more efficient.

You
Cannot resolve component getCenterPoint
ChatGPT

The getCenterPoint method needs to be defined within your WorkSpacePanel class to calculate the center point of the shapes representing WordBlock objects. This method is used to determine the start and end points of the lines representing the connections.

Here’s how you can define the getCenterPoint method in your WorkSpacePanel class:

java
private Point getCenterPoint(Shape shape) {
    Rectangle2D bounds = shape.getBounds2D();
    int centerX = (int) bounds.getCenterX();
    int centerY = (int) bounds.getCenterY();
    return new Point(centerX, centerY);
}

This method calculates the center point of the given Shape object, which is used as a reference to draw the lines between connected WordBlock instances.

Make sure you add this method inside your WorkSpacePanel class where you have access to the shapes and where you are doing the drawing operations. This method will be used in your paintComponent method when drawing connections:

java
// Draw connections
g2.setColor(Color.BLACK);
for (Connection conn : connections) {
    Point fromPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getFrom()));
    Point toPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getTo()));
    g2.drawLine(fromPoint.x, fromPoint.y, toPoint.x, toPoint.y);
}

This way, getCenterPoint provides the central coordinates for each WordBlock shape, which you then use to draw the connecting lines.

You
Is there someway to draw connections as the lowest element on the WorkSpace so that they don't cover the WordBlocks
ChatGPT

To ensure that the connections are drawn as the lowest element on the WorkSpacePanel, and thus don’t cover the WordBlock objects, you should draw them first in the paintComponent method of your panel. This way, when you subsequently draw the WordBlock shapes, they will appear on top of the lines representing the connections.

Here’s how you can adjust the paintComponent method to draw connections at the lowest layer:

java
@Override
protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
    super.paintComponent(g);
    Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g;

    // Draw connections first so they are under the WordBlocks
    g2.setColor(Color.BLACK); // Or any color for the connections
    for (Connection conn : connections) {
        Point fromPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getFrom()));
        Point toPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getTo()));
        g2.drawLine(fromPoint.x, fromPoint.y, toPoint.x, toPoint.y);
    }

    // Then draw WordBlocks on top
    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
        WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey();
        Shape shape = entry.getValue();

        g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); // Background color
        g2.fill(shape);

        g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); // Text color
        g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20);
        g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40);

        // If this is the selected word block, draw a highlight border around it
        if (wordBlock == selectedWordBlock) {
            g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2)); // Set stroke width for the highlight
            g2.setColor(Color.BLUE); // Highlight color
            g2.draw(shape); // Draw the highlight around the shape
        }
    }
}

In this paintComponent method:

  • Connections are drawn first, using lines connecting the center points of the WordBlock shapes.
  • Each WordBlock and its text are drawn afterward, which ensures that the WordBlock objects appear on top of the connection lines.
  • This ordering maintains the visual hierarchy, making sure that the WordBlock objects are not obscured by the connection lines.

ChatGPT

A ConcurrentModificationException typically occurs when a collection (like an ArrayList) is modified while it is being iterated over. This can happen in single-threaded environments like the Swing event dispatch thread when you modify a collection within a loop that is iterating over that collection.

From the stack trace, it seems the exception occurs when trying to remove a WordBlock from a collection (WorkSpace.removeWordBlock) triggered by an action (likely from a JPopupMenu in WorkSpacePanel). Here's what likely happened:

  • While iterating over a collection (e.g., iterating over wordBlockShapes or a similar list to draw, hit-test, or perform another operation), an element is being removed from that collection.
  • This modification invalidates the iterator, leading to the ConcurrentModificationException.

To resolve this issue, you should avoid modifying the collection directly while it is being iterated. Here are a few strategies to handle this:

  1. Use a Copy for Iteration: Iterate over a copy of the collection while modifying the original one.

    java
    for (WordBlock wordBlock : new ArrayList<>(wordBlockShapes.keySet())) {
    // operations that might modify wordBlockShapes
}

  2. Collect Items to Remove: Instead of removing items during iteration, collect them in a separate list and remove them after the iteration completes.

    java
    List<WordBlock> toRemove = new ArrayList<>();
for (WordBlock wordBlock : wordBlockShapes.keySet()) {
    if (shouldBeRemoved(wordBlock)) {
        toRemove.add(wordBlock);
    }
}
wordBlockShapes.keySet().removeAll(toRemove);

  3. Use Concurrent Collections: If modifications from multiple threads are involved, consider using thread-safe collections like ConcurrentHashMap. However, in Swing, most actions are performed on the event dispatch thread, so this might not be necessary unless you're specifically dealing with multi-threading.

The exact fix will depend on the logic of your WorkSpace.removeWordBlock method and where the iteration and modification are happening. You need to make sure you're not changing the collection you're iterating over within the same loop to avoid this exception.

You
I've rethought the architecture of WorkSpace. Its now two seperate lists. How can I make sure I'm deleting all connections involving the wordBlock I want to delete: package LinguaLink.containers.workspace; import LinguaLink.components.connection.Connection; import LinguaLink.components.word.Word; import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock; import java.lang.reflect.Array; import java.util.ArrayList; import java.util.Collections; import java.util.List; import java.awt.Point; public class WorkSpace { private static WorkSpace workSpace = null; private ArrayList<WordBlock> wordBlocks; private ArrayList<Connection> connections; private WorkSpace() { wordBlocks = new ArrayList<>(); connections = new ArrayList<>(); } public static WorkSpace getInstance() { if (workSpace == null) { workSpace = new WorkSpace(); } return workSpace; } public void clearWorkSpace() { connections.clear(); wordBlocks.clear(); } public List<WordBlock> getWordBlocks() { return Collections.unmodifiableList(wordBlocks); } public List<Connection> getConnections() { return Collections.unmodifiableList(connections); } public void addWord(Word word) { WordBlock newWordBlock = new WordBlock(new Point(0, 0), word); wordBlocks.add(newWordBlock); } public void removeWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) { wordBlocks.remove(wordBlock); for (Connection c : connections) { if (c.contains(wordBlock)) { connections.remove(c); } } } public void removeConnection(Connection toDelete) { connections.remove(toDelete); } public void addConnection(Connection toAdd) { connections.add(toAdd); } }
2 / 2
ChatGPT

In your current implementation of removeWordBlock, you're attempting to modify the connections list while iterating over it, which can lead to ConcurrentModificationException. To safely remove all connections involving the specified WordBlock, you should first collect the connections to be removed and then remove them after the iteration is complete.

Here's how you can modify the removeWordBlock method to avoid concurrent modification issues:

java
public void removeWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) {
    wordBlocks.remove(wordBlock);
    
    // Collect connections to remove
    List<Connection> toRemove = new ArrayList<>();
    for (Connection c : connections) {
        if (c.getFrom().equals(wordBlock) || c.getTo().equals(wordBlock)) {
            toRemove.add(c);
        }
    }
    
    // Remove the collected connections
    connections.removeAll(toRemove);
}

In this revised method:

  1. Iterate through the connections list to find any connections that involve wordBlock.
  2. Add these connections to a temporary list toRemove.
  3. After completing the iteration, use connections.removeAll(toRemove) to remove all the collected connections in one operation.

This approach prevents the ConcurrentModificationException because the connections list is not being modified while it is being iterated. Instead, the actual removal happens after the iteration is complete, which is a safe operation.

You
I'm now having an issue with the following class. I can select a wordBlock, I see that its selected because of the highlight. I then (without deselecting the WordBlock) right click another wordBlock. It instead deletes the highlighted block not the one I just right clicked WordBlock. package LinguaLink.guiComponents.workSpacePanel; import LinguaLink.Controller; import LinguaLink.Model; import LinguaLink.Util; import LinguaLink.components.connection.Connection; import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock; import LinguaLink.logger.Logger; import javax.swing.*; import java.awt.*; import java.awt.event.MouseAdapter; import java.awt.event.MouseEvent; import java.awt.event.MouseMotionAdapter; import java.awt.geom.Rectangle2D; import java.awt.geom.RoundRectangle2D; import java.util.ArrayList; import java.util.HashMap; import java.util.List; import java.util.Map; public class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel { private Map<WordBlock, Shape> wordBlockShapes = new HashMap<>(); private WordBlock draggedWordBlock; private Point lastDragPoint; private Controller controller; private Model model; private WordBlock selectedWordBlock; private WordBlock firstSelectedBlock; public WorkSpacePanel() { controller = Controller.getInstance(); model = Model.getInstance(); setBackground(Color.WHITE); setFocusable(true); setupMouseHandling(); createPopupMenu(); } private void setupMouseHandling() { MouseAdapter mouseAdapter = new MouseAdapter() { @Override public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) { requestFocusInWindow(); WordBlock clickedBlock = null; boolean clickedOnBlock = false; for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) { clickedBlock = entry.getKey(); clickedOnBlock = true; lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); // Set initial drag point // Select or drag the block if (SwingUtilities.isLeftMouseButton(e)) { if (e.isShiftDown() && firstSelectedBlock != null && clickedBlock != firstSelectedBlock) { controller.addConnection(new Connection(firstSelectedBlock, clickedBlock)); firstSelectedBlock = null; // Reset for the next connection } else { firstSelectedBlock = clickedBlock; draggedWordBlock = clickedBlock; selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // For highlighting or other actions } } // Show the popup menu on right click if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) { createPopupMenu().show(WorkSpacePanel.this, e.getX(), e.getY()); } break; } } if (!clickedOnBlock) { selectedWordBlock = null; firstSelectedBlock = null; draggedWordBlock = null; } repaint(); // Repaint to update the workspace } @Override public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e) { draggedWordBlock = null; lastDragPoint = null; } @Override public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) { if (draggedWordBlock != null && lastDragPoint != null) { int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x; int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y; Shape shape = wordBlockShapes.get(draggedWordBlock); if (shape instanceof RoundRectangle2D) { RoundRectangle2D rect = (RoundRectangle2D) shape; rect.setFrame(rect.getX() + dx, rect.getY() + dy, rect.getWidth(), rect.getHeight()); } lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); controller.setWordBlockPosition(draggedWordBlock, dx, dy); repaint(); } } }; addMouseListener(mouseAdapter); addMouseMotionListener(mouseAdapter); // Use the same adapter for motion events } private JPopupMenu createPopupMenu() { JPopupMenu popupMenu = new JPopupMenu(); JMenuItem moveToBankItem = new JMenuItem("Move to Word Bank"); moveToBankItem.addActionListener(e -> { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { controller.moveWordToWordBank(selectedWordBlock); wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock); repaint(); } }); JMenuItem deleteItem = new JMenuItem("Delete"); deleteItem.addActionListener(e -> { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { safeDeleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock); } }); popupMenu.add(moveToBankItem); popupMenu.add(deleteItem); return popupMenu; } public void addWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) { RoundRectangle2D roundRect = new RoundRectangle2D.Double( wordBlock.getPosition().x, wordBlock.getPosition().y, 100, 50, 10, 10); wordBlockShapes.put(wordBlock, roundRect); } public void clearWordBlocks() { wordBlockShapes.clear(); repaint(); } protected void safeDeleteWordBlock(WordBlock toDelete) { wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock); controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock); selectedWordBlock = null; repaint(); } @Override protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) { super.paintComponent(g); Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g; // Draw connections List<Connection> connectionList = model.getActiveConnections(); g2.setColor(Color.BLACK); for (Connection conn : connectionList) { Point fromPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getFrom())); Point toPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getTo())); g2.drawLine(fromPoint.x, fromPoint.y, toPoint.x, toPoint.y); } for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey(); Shape shape = entry.getValue(); // Fill the shape with its background color g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.fill(shape); // Draw text inside the shape g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40); // If this is the selected word block, draw a highlight border around it if (wordBlock == selectedWordBlock) { g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2)); // Set stroke width for the highlight g2.setColor(Color.BLUE); // Highlight color g2.draw(shape); // Draw the highlight around the shape } } } private Point getCenterPoint(Shape shape) { Rectangle2D bounds = shape.getBounds2D(); int centerX = (int) bounds.getCenterX(); int centerY = (int) bounds.getCenterY(); return new Point(centerX, centerY); } }
ChatGPT

The problem you're encountering is due to the logic in the mousePressed method. The selectedWordBlock is set before you right-click to show the popup menu, leading to actions being performed on the previously selected block rather than the one you right-clicked.

To ensure that the right-clicked WordBlock is the one affected by the popup menu actions, you need to update the selectedWordBlock before showing the popup menu. Here's how you can modify the mousePressed method to address this issue:

  1. Update the selectedWordBlock upon a right-click before showing the popup menu.
  2. Ensure the popup menu is shown for the right-clicked block.

Here's the modified mousePressed method:

java
@Override
public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
    requestFocusInWindow();
    WordBlock clickedBlock = null;
    boolean clickedOnBlock = false;
    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
        if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
            clickedBlock = entry.getKey();
            clickedOnBlock = true;
            lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); // Set initial drag point

            if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) {
                selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // Update the selected block on right-click
                createPopupMenu().show(WorkSpacePanel.this, e.getX(), e.getY());
            } else if (SwingUtilities.isLeftMouseButton(e)) {
                if (e.isShiftDown() && firstSelectedBlock != null && clickedBlock != firstSelectedBlock) {
                    controller.addConnection(new Connection(firstSelectedBlock, clickedBlock));
                    firstSelectedBlock = null; // Reset for the next connection
                } else {
                    firstSelectedBlock = clickedBlock;
                    draggedWordBlock = clickedBlock;
                    selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // For highlighting or other actions
                }
            }
            break;
        }
    }

    if (!clickedOnBlock && SwingUtilities.isLeftMouseButton(e)) {
        selectedWordBlock = null;
        firstSelectedBlock = null;
        draggedWordBlock = null;
    }

    repaint(); // Repaint to update the workspace
}

In this updated method:

  • The selectedWordBlock is set to the block that was right-clicked immediately before showing the popup menu. This ensures that the actions in the popup menu affect the correct WordBlock.
  • The block is only set as selectedWordBlock for highlighting and action purposes when left-clicked, or right-clicked for the popup menu.
  • The logic ensures that the selectedWordBlock is correctly assigned based on the user's action, so the popup menu actions are performed on the correct block.
You
Implement double click logic, and add an empty callback function
ChatGPT

To implement double-click logic for a WordBlock in the WorkSpacePanel, you can modify the mousePressed method within the MouseAdapter. You will need to detect double-click events and then execute the desired action. Here's how you can integrate double-click detection and handle it with an empty callback function:

  1. Check for double-clicks in the mousePressed method.
  2. Define a method that will act as the callback for double-click actions.

Here's an updated version of the mousePressed method along with an example of how you might set up the callback method:

java
private void setupMouseHandling() {
    MouseAdapter mouseAdapter = new MouseAdapter() {
        @Override
        public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
            requestFocusInWindow();
            WordBlock clickedBlock = null;
            for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
                if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
                    clickedBlock = entry.getKey();

                    if (e.getClickCount() == 2) {
                        onDoubleClick(clickedBlock); // Handle double-click
                    } else if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) {
                        selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // Update the selected block on right-click
                        createPopupMenu().show(WorkSpacePanel.this, e.getX(), e.getY());
                    } else if (SwingUtilities.isLeftMouseButton(e)) {
                        if (!e.isShiftDown()) {
                            draggedWordBlock = clickedBlock;
                            selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // For highlighting or other actions
                        }
                        lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); // Set initial drag point
                    }
                    break;
                }
            }

            if (!clickedBlock && SwingUtilities.isLeftMouseButton(e)) {
                selectedWordBlock = null;
                draggedWordBlock = null;
                firstSelectedBlock = null;
            }

            repaint(); // Repaint to update the workspace
        }

        @Override
        public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e) {
            draggedWordBlock = null;
            lastDragPoint = null;
        }

        @Override
        public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) {
            if (draggedWordBlock != null && lastDragPoint != null) {
                int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x;
                int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y;
                Shape shape = wordBlockShapes.get(draggedWordBlock);
                if (shape instanceof RoundRectangle2D) {
                    RoundRectangle2D rect = (RoundRectangle2D) shape;
                    rect.setFrame(rect.getX() + dx, rect.getY() + dy, rect.getWidth(), rect.getHeight());
                }
                lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();
                controller.setWordBlockPosition(draggedWordBlock, dx, dy);
                repaint();
            }
        }
    };

    addMouseListener(mouseAdapter);
    addMouseMotionListener(mouseAdapter); // Use the same adapter for motion events
}

private void onDoubleClick(WordBlock wordBlock) {
    // This is where you handle the double-click action on a WordBlock
    Logger.info("Double-clicked on WordBlock: " + wordBlock.getWord().getWord());
    // Implement the desired double-click behavior here
}

In the code above:

  • The mousePressed method checks if the mouse event is a double-click (e.getClickCount() == 2) on a WordBlock and calls the onDoubleClick method.
  • The onDoubleClick method is defined to handle double-click actions. Right now, it just logs the double-click action, but you can extend it to perform any required functionality.
  • The selectedWordBlock is updated right before showing the popup menu to ensure the actions in the menu affect the right block.
You
What are the Swing classes implementing the Stroke interface?
ChatGPT

In Java Swing, the Stroke interface itself is not a part of the Swing package but rather the Java 2D API, which is used for setting the graphics state during rendering operations. The Stroke interface allows you to define the outline of the shapes drawn by a Graphics2D object. While Swing doesn't have specific classes implementing the Stroke interface, Java 2D provides several implementations that you can use in Swing applications to control the drawing of lines and shape borders.

The primary Java 2D class implementing the Stroke interface is:

  • BasicStroke: This is the most commonly used implementation of the Stroke interface. It defines a basic set of rendering attributes for the outlines of graphics primitives, such as line width, end caps, line joins, and miter limit. You can use it to create solid lines of various widths, dashed lines, and so on.

Example of using BasicStroke:

java
float[] dashPattern = {10, 10}; // Define a dash pattern (10 pixels filled, 10 pixels empty)
BasicStroke dashed = new BasicStroke(
    2,                      // Line width
    BasicStroke.CAP_SQUARE, // End cap style
    BasicStroke.JOIN_MITER, // Join style
    10,                     // Miter limit
    dashPattern,            // Dash pattern
    0                       // Dash phase
);

Graphics2D g2d = (Graphics2D) g; // Assuming 'g' is a Graphics object passed to a painting method
g2d.setStroke(dashed);
g2d.drawLine(10, 10, 200, 10); // Draw a dashed line using the defined stroke

While BasicStroke is the primary concrete class in the Java 2D API that implements the Stroke interface, other classes and third-party libraries may also provide their own implementations of Stroke for more specialized effects. However, in the standard Java 2D API, BasicStroke is the main class you would typically use to manipulate how shapes and lines are stroked on the screen.

You
What if I want to set the color of a basic stroke
ChatGPT

In Java 2D, the color of a stroke is not a property of the Stroke itself but rather of the Graphics2D object used to draw shapes and lines. The Stroke defines the shape of the outline (such as its width, end caps, and dash pattern), but the color is set separately on the Graphics2D context.

To set the color of a stroke, you use the setColor method of the Graphics2D object before drawing the shape or line. Here’s how you can do it:

  1. Set the color on the Graphics2D object.
  2. Set the stroke on the Graphics2D object.
  3. Draw your shape or line.

Here is an example that sets the stroke and color before drawing:

java
Graphics2D g2d = (Graphics2D) g; // 'g' is a Graphics object passed to your paintComponent or similar method

// Set the color for the stroke
g2d.setColor(Color.RED); // Set the color you want for the line

// Create and set the stroke
BasicStroke stroke = new BasicStroke(2); // Define a basic stroke with a width of 2 pixels
g2d.setStroke(stroke);

// Draw a line (or any shape) with the defined stroke and color
g2d.drawLine(10, 10, 100, 100); // Draw a line with the current stroke and color

In this example, setColor is called before setStroke, ensuring that the line drawn with drawLine (or any drawing method like drawRect, drawOval, etc.) uses the specified color and stroke style. The order of setting the color and the stroke is crucial because the Graphics2D context uses the current settings at the time of the draw call to render the shape.

You
Is there some way to thicken the connection lines?
ChatGPT

Yes, you can thicken the connection lines by using the BasicStroke class in Java 2D, which allows you to set the thickness (width) of the lines. Here is how you can do it:

  1. Create an instance of BasicStroke with the desired line thickness.
  2. Set this stroke on the Graphics2D object before drawing the lines.

Here’s an example of how you can modify the paintComponent method in your WorkSpacePanel class to use a thicker stroke for the connection lines:

java
@Override
protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
    super.paintComponent(g);
    Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g;

    // Set a thicker stroke for the connection lines
    float strokeWidth = 3.0f; // Specify the thickness of the line
    BasicStroke thickStroke = new BasicStroke(strokeWidth);
    g2.setStroke(thickStroke);

    // Draw connection lines with the specified thick stroke
    g2.setColor(Color.BLACK); // Set the color for the connection lines
    for (Connection conn : model.getActiveConnections()) {
        Point fromPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getFrom()));
        Point toPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getTo()));
        g2.drawLine(fromPoint.x, fromPoint.y, toPoint.x, toPoint.y);
    }

    // Reset to default stroke for drawing other elements
    g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke()); // Resetting to default stroke for other graphics operations

    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
        WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey();
        Shape shape = entry.getValue();

        // Draw the WordBlocks with their details
        g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech()));
        g2.fill(shape);

        g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech()));
        g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20);
        g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40);

        if (wordBlock == selectedWordBlock) {
            g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2)); // Set stroke width for the highlight
            g2.setColor(Color.BLUE); // Highlight color
            g2.draw(shape); // Draw the highlight around the shape
            g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke()); // Reset stroke after highlighting
        }
    }
}

In this example, the stroke width is set to 3.0 pixels, but you can adjust the strokeWidth variable to make the connection lines as thick as you need. Setting the stroke on the Graphics2D object before drawing the lines will apply this stroke style to the lines drawn afterward. Remember to reset the stroke to the default if you want to draw other elements with different stroke properties.

You
Why would this be drawing only thick red strokes? Something with the isValid function? @Override protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) { super.paintComponent(g); Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g; // Draw connections List<Connection> connectionList = model.getActiveConnections(); for (Connection conn : connectionList) { Point fromPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getFrom())); Point toPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getTo())); if (conn.isValid()) { g2.setColor(Color.BLACK); g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(5.0f)); } else { g2.setColor(Color.RED); g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(10.0f)); } g2.drawLine(fromPoint.x, fromPoint.y, toPoint.x, toPoint.y); } g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke()); for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey(); Shape shape = entry.getValue(); // Fill the shape with its background color g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.fill(shape); // Draw text inside the shape g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40); // If this is the selected word block, draw a highlight border around it if (wordBlock == selectedWordBlock) { g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2)); // Set stroke width for the highlight g2.setColor(Color.BLUE); // Highlight color g2.draw(shape); // Draw the highlight around the shape } } }
ChatGPT

The issue might be due to how the isValid method of the Connection class behaves. If all connections are being drawn with thick red strokes, it likely means conn.isValid() is returning false for every connection, causing the block inside the else condition to execute every time.

To debug and solve this:

  1. Check isValid Implementation: Make sure the isValid method of the Connection class is implemented correctly and returns true when you expect the connection to be valid.

  2. Reset Graphics State: Ensure that the graphics state (color and stroke) is reset appropriately for each type of drawing operation. After drawing connections, if you change the stroke or color, it should be set back to what's needed for the next drawing operations.

  3. Stroke Reset Timing: After drawing all connections, you reset the stroke to default with g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke()); which is good practice. However, ensure this reset action doesn't interfere with subsequent drawings that require a specific stroke.

Here’s a refined version of your paintComponent method to emphasize these points:

java
@Override
protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) {
    super.paintComponent(g);
    Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g;

    // Draw connections
    List<Connection> connectionList = model.getActiveConnections();
    for (Connection conn : connectionList) {
        Point fromPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getFrom()));
        Point toPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getTo()));

        if (conn.isValid()) {
            g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(5.0f));
            g2.setColor(Color.BLACK);
        } else {
            g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(10.0f));
            g2.setColor(Color.RED);
        }

        g2.drawLine(fromPoint.x, fromPoint.y, toPoint.x, toPoint.y);
    }

    // Reset to default stroke for other graphics operations
    g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke());

    for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
        WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey();
        Shape shape = entry.getValue();

        // Set color and fill shape for word blocks
        g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech()));
        g2.fill(shape);

        // Draw text inside the shape
        g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech()));
        g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20);
        g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40);

        // Highlight if selected
        if (wordBlock == selectedWordBlock) {
            g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2)); // Set stroke width for highlight
            g2.setColor(Color.BLUE); // Set highlight color
            g2.draw(shape); // Draw highlight
            g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke()); // Reset stroke after highlight
        }
    }
}

This structured approach helps maintain the clarity of what graphical attributes are applied at what time, reducing the likelihood of unexpected behavior due to the lingering state from previous drawing commands.

You
Will the last else if work the way I think it does? public boolean isValid() { PartOfSpeech fromPos = from.getWord().getPartOfSpeech(); PartOfSpeech toPos = from.getWord().getPartOfSpeech(); List<PartOfSpeech> places = Arrays.asList(PartOfSpeech.NOUN, PartOfSpeech.PRONOUN, PartOfSpeech.CONJUNCTION, PartOfSpeech.CONJUNCTION, PartOfSpeech.PREPOSITION, PartOfSpeech.ARTICLE); if (fromPos == PartOfSpeech.NOUN && toPos == PartOfSpeech.ADJECTIVE) { return false; } else if (fromPos == PartOfSpeech.ADJECTIVE && toPos == PartOfSpeech.VERB) { return false; } else if (fromPos == PartOfSpeech.ADVERB && toPos == PartOfSpeech.NOUN) { return false; } else if (fromPos == PartOfSpeech.PREPOSITION && toPos == PartOfSpeech.VERB) { return false; } else if (fromPos == toPos && places.contains(fromPos)) { return false; } return true; } public boolean contains(WordBlock wordBlock) { return (from == wordBlock || to == wordBlock); } }
ChatGPT

The logic in your isValid method mostly makes sense according to the specific rules you've set up for the PartOfSpeech relationships, but there seems to be a mistake in how you retrieve toPos. You're getting the part of speech from from.getWord().getPartOfSpeech() twice, instead of getting it from to for the second one. It should be:

java
PartOfSpeech toPos = to.getWord().getPartOfSpeech();

Regarding the else if that checks if fromPos equals toPos and if places contains fromPos, it will work logically as you described, meaning it will return false if both from and to have the same PartOfSpeech that is in the places list.

Here's the corrected method:

java
public boolean isValid() {
    PartOfSpeech fromPos = from.getWord().getPartOfSpeech();
    PartOfSpeech toPos = to.getWord().getPartOfSpeech();  // Corrected to get PartOfSpeech from 'to'

    List<PartOfSpeech> places = Arrays.asList(
        PartOfSpeech.NOUN, PartOfSpeech.PRONOUN, PartOfSpeech.CONJUNCTION, 
        PartOfSpeech.PREPOSITION, PartOfSpeech.ARTICLE
    );  // Removed duplicate CONJUNCTION

    if (fromPos == PartOfSpeech.NOUN && toPos == PartOfSpeech.ADJECTIVE) {
        return false;
    } else if (fromPos == PartOfSpeech.ADJECTIVE && toPos == PartOfSpeech.VERB) {
        return false;
    } else if (fromPos == PartOfSpeech.ADVERB && toPos == PartOfSpeech.NOUN) {
        return false;
    } else if (fromPos == PartOfSpeech.PREPOSITION && toPos == PartOfSpeech.VERB) {
        return false;
    }  else if (fromPos == toPos && places.contains(fromPos)) {
        return false;
    }
    return true;
}

This method now correctly checks the PartOfSpeech of both from and to and contains the logic you described, which seems to make sure that specific connections between word types are evaluated as valid or invalid according to your rules. If from and to are of the same PartOfSpeech and this PartOfSpeech is one of the ones listed in places, the connection is considered invalid.

You
Is it possible to drag and select multiple WordBlocks at the same time, then delete them? package LinguaLink.guiComponents.workSpacePanel; import LinguaLink.Controller; import LinguaLink.Model; import LinguaLink.Util; import LinguaLink.components.connection.Connection; import LinguaLink.components.wordblock.WordBlock; import javax.swing.*; import java.awt.*; import java.awt.event.MouseAdapter; import java.awt.event.MouseEvent; import java.awt.geom.Rectangle2D; import java.awt.geom.RoundRectangle2D; import java.util.HashMap; import java.util.List; import java.util.Map; public class WorkSpacePanel extends JPanel { private Map<WordBlock, Shape> wordBlockShapes = new HashMap<>(); private WordBlock draggedWordBlock; private Point lastDragPoint; private Controller controller; private Model model; private WordBlock selectedWordBlock; private WordBlock firstSelectedBlock; public WorkSpacePanel() { controller = Controller.getInstance(); model = Model.getInstance(); setBackground(Color.WHITE); setFocusable(true); setupMouseHandling(); createPopupMenu(); } private void setupMouseHandling() { MouseAdapter mouseAdapter = new MouseAdapter() { @Override public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) { requestFocusInWindow(); WordBlock clickedBlock = null; boolean clickedOnBlock = false; for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) { clickedBlock = entry.getKey(); clickedOnBlock = true; lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); // Set initial drag point if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) { selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // Update the selected block on right-click createPopupMenu().show(WorkSpacePanel.this, e.getX(), e.getY()); } else if (SwingUtilities.isLeftMouseButton(e)) { if (e.getClickCount() == 2) { controller.moveWordToWordBank(clickedBlock); } else if (e.isShiftDown() && firstSelectedBlock != null && clickedBlock != firstSelectedBlock) { controller.addConnection(new Connection(firstSelectedBlock, clickedBlock)); firstSelectedBlock = null; // Reset for the next connection } else { firstSelectedBlock = clickedBlock; draggedWordBlock = clickedBlock; selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // For highlighting or other actions } } break; } } if (!clickedOnBlock && SwingUtilities.isLeftMouseButton(e)) { selectedWordBlock = null; firstSelectedBlock = null; draggedWordBlock = null; } repaint(); } @Override public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent e) { draggedWordBlock = null; lastDragPoint = null; } @Override public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) { if (draggedWordBlock != null && lastDragPoint != null) { int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x; int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y; Shape shape = wordBlockShapes.get(draggedWordBlock); if (shape instanceof RoundRectangle2D) { RoundRectangle2D rect = (RoundRectangle2D) shape; rect.setFrame(rect.getX() + dx, rect.getY() + dy, rect.getWidth(), rect.getHeight()); } lastDragPoint = e.getPoint(); controller.setWordBlockPosition(draggedWordBlock, dx, dy); repaint(); } } }; addMouseListener(mouseAdapter); addMouseMotionListener(mouseAdapter); // Use the same adapter for motion events } private JPopupMenu createPopupMenu() { JPopupMenu popupMenu = new JPopupMenu(); JMenuItem moveToBankItem = new JMenuItem("Move to Word Bank"); moveToBankItem.addActionListener(e -> { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { controller.moveWordToWordBank(selectedWordBlock); wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock); repaint(); } }); JMenuItem deleteItem = new JMenuItem("Delete"); deleteItem.addActionListener(e -> { if (selectedWordBlock != null) { safeDeleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock); } }); popupMenu.add(moveToBankItem); popupMenu.add(deleteItem); return popupMenu; } public void addWordBlock(WordBlock wordBlock) { RoundRectangle2D roundRect = new RoundRectangle2D.Double( wordBlock.getPosition().x, wordBlock.getPosition().y, 100, 50, 10, 10); wordBlockShapes.put(wordBlock, roundRect); } public void clearWordBlocks() { wordBlockShapes.clear(); repaint(); } protected void safeDeleteWordBlock(WordBlock toDelete) { wordBlockShapes.remove(selectedWordBlock); controller.deleteWordBlock(selectedWordBlock); selectedWordBlock = null; repaint(); } @Override protected void paintComponent(Graphics g) { super.paintComponent(g); Graphics2D g2 = (Graphics2D) g; // Draw connections List<Connection> connectionList = model.getActiveConnections(); for (Connection conn : connectionList) { Point fromPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getFrom())); Point toPoint = getCenterPoint(wordBlockShapes.get(conn.getTo())); if (conn.isValid()) { g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(5.0f)); g2.setColor(Color.BLACK); } else { g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(10.0f)); g2.setColor(Color.RED); } g2.drawLine(fromPoint.x, fromPoint.y, toPoint.x, toPoint.y); } // Reset to default stroke for other graphics operations g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke()); for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) { WordBlock wordBlock = entry.getKey(); Shape shape = entry.getValue(); // Set color and fill shape for word blocks g2.setColor(Util.getBackgroundColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.fill(shape); // Draw text inside the shape g2.setColor(Util.getPrimaryTextColor(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech())); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getWord(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 20); g2.drawString(wordBlock.getWord().getPartOfSpeech().toString(), (float) shape.getBounds().getX() + 5, (float) shape.getBounds().getY() + 40); // Highlight if selected if (wordBlock == selectedWordBlock) { g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke(2)); // Set stroke width for highlight g2.setColor(Color.BLUE); // Set highlight color g2.draw(shape); // Draw highlight g2.setStroke(new BasicStroke()); // Reset stroke after highlight } } } private Point getCenterPoint(Shape shape) { Rectangle2D bounds = shape.getBounds2D(); int centerX = (int) bounds.getCenterX(); int centerY = (int) bounds.getCenterY(); return new Point(centerX, centerY); } }
ChatGPT

To implement functionality for selecting multiple WordBlock instances at the same time, dragging them, and then deleting them upon request, you need to modify how you manage selections and handle drag-and-drop operations in your WorkSpacePanel class.

Here’s how you can adjust your implementation:

  1. Track Multiple Selections: Instead of having a single selectedWordBlock, use a collection (like Set<WordBlock>) to keep track of all selected blocks.

  2. Update Mouse Handling: Modify your mouse handling logic to support multi-selection and handle drag operations for all selected blocks.

  3. Delete Multiple Blocks: Adapt your delete action to remove all selected blocks.

Here's an example of how you can start modifying your code:

java
import java.util.HashSet;
import java.util.Set;

// Inside WorkSpacePanel class

private Set<WordBlock> selectedWordBlocks = new HashSet<>();

private void setupMouseHandling() {
    MouseAdapter mouseAdapter = new MouseAdapter() {
        @Override
        public void mousePressed(MouseEvent e) {
            requestFocusInWindow();
            WordBlock clickedBlock = null;
            
            for (Map.Entry<WordBlock, Shape> entry : wordBlockShapes.entrySet()) {
                if (entry.getValue().contains(e.getPoint())) {
                    clickedBlock = entry.getKey();
                    lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();  // Set initial drag point

                    if (SwingUtilities.isLeftMouseButton(e)) {
                        if (e.isShiftDown()) {
                            // Toggle selection with shift click
                            if (selectedWordBlocks.contains(clickedBlock)) {
                                selectedWordBlocks.remove(clickedBlock);
                            } else {
                                selectedWordBlocks.add(clickedBlock);
                            }
                        } else {
                            selectedWordBlocks.clear();
                            selectedWordBlocks.add(clickedBlock);
                        }
                        draggedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // Consider last clicked block as dragged
                    }

                    if (SwingUtilities.isRightMouseButton(e)) {
                        // Show popup menu for right-click on any word block
                        selectedWordBlock = clickedBlock; // Update the last right-clicked block for menu actions
                        createPopupMenu().show(WorkSpacePanel.this, e.getX(), e.getY());
                    }

                    break;
                }
            }

            if (!selectedWordBlocks.contains(clickedBlock) && SwingUtilities.isLeftMouseButton(e)) {
                selectedWordBlocks.clear();
            }

            repaint();  // Repaint to update the workspace
        }

        @Override
        public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent e) {
            if (!selectedWordBlocks.isEmpty() && lastDragPoint != null) {
                int dx = e.getX() - lastDragPoint.x;
                int dy = e.getY() - lastDragPoint.y;

                for (WordBlock selectedBlock : selectedWordBlocks) {
                    Shape shape = wordBlockShapes.get(selectedBlock);
                    if (shape instanceof RoundRectangle2D) {
                        RoundRectangle2D rect = (RoundRectangle2D) shape;
                        rect.setFrame(rect.getX() + dx, rect.getY() + dy, rect.getWidth(), rect.getHeight());
                    }
                }

                lastDragPoint = e.getPoint();
                repaint();
            }
        }
    };

    addMouseListener(mouseAdapter);
    addMouseMotionListener(mouseAdapter); // Use the same adapter for motion events
}

private void safeDeleteWordBlock() {
    for (WordBlock block : selectedWordBlocks) {
        wordBlockShapes.remove(block);
        controller.deleteWordBlock(block);
    }
    selectedWordBlocks.clear();
    repaint();
}
  • Selection Logic: This code allows selecting multiple WordBlock instances using shift-click. If you click on a block without the shift key pressed, it clears the existing selection and selects the new block.
  • Dragging Logic: When dragging, it moves all selected WordBlock instances together.
  • Deletion Logic: safeDeleteWordBlock method deletes all selected word blocks.

This setup should enable you to select, drag, and delete multiple blocks in your workspace.

You
How could I add a trash can icon to each WordBlock that acts as a delete that WordBlock button?
ChatGPT

To add a "trash can" icon to each WordBlock that acts as a delete button, you can modify your rendering in the WorkSpacePanel to include an icon within the bounds of each WordBlock. Here are the steps to achieve this:

  1. Add Trash Can Icon: Include a trash can icon in your project resources and load it in your WorkSpacePanel class.
